tr.td: True iff G is in this graph class.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the treewidth of G is at most k (see bounded treewidth).
A graph G in this class.

An expression that constructs G according to the rules for cliquewidth, using only a constant number of labels.
Undefined if this class has unbounded cliquewidth.
A graph G in this class.

An expression that constructs G according to the rules for booleanwidth, using only a constant number of labels.
Undefined if this class has unbounded booleanwidth.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at least k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, such that |S| >= k.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, with the sum of the weights of the vertices in S at most k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise non-adjacent vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise adjacent vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at least k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of pairwise adjacent vertices, with |S| >= k.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every vertex in G is either in S or adjacent to a vertex in S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff each vertex of G can be assigned one colour out of k such that whenever two vertices are adjacent, they have different colours.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into k sets Si, such that whenever two vertices are in the same set Si, they are adjacent.
A graph G in this class.
True iff each vertex of G can be assigned one colour out of 3 such that whenever two vertices are adjacent, they have different colours.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff the cutwidth of G is at most k (see bounded cutwidth).
A graph G in this class.
True iff G has a simple cycle that goes through every vertex of the graph.
A graph G in this class.
True iff G has a simple path that goes through every vertex of the graph.
A graph G in this class with weight function on the vertices and a real k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, such that the sum of the weights of the vertices in S is at most k and every cycle in G contains a vertex from S.
A graph G in this class and an integer k.
True iff G contains a set S of vertices, with |S| <= k, such that every cycle in G contains a vertex from S.

Problem.name: Weighted maximum cut
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class with weight function on the edges and a real k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B such that the sum of weights of the edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B is at least k.

Problem.name: Maximum cut
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B such that there are at least k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

Problem.name: Maximum bisection
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B of equal size (or |A|=|B|-1 if G has an odd number of vertices) such that there are at least k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

Problem.name: Minimum bisection
Problem.note:
(decision variant)
Input:A graph G in this class and an integer k.
Output:True iff the vertices of G can be partitioned into two sets A,B of equal size (or |A|=|B|-1 if G has an odd number of vertices) such that there are at most k edges in G with one endpoint in A and the other endpoint in B.

tr.td: Graphs G and H in this class
True iff G and H are isomorphic.

Parameter.name: Booleanwidth
Parameter.note: Decomposition of a graph $G$ is a pair $(T,L)$where $T$ is a sub-cubic tree and $L$ is a bijection from $V(G)$ to the leaves of thetree $T$.The function cut-bool : $2^{V(G)} \rightarrow R$ is defined as\begin{center}cut-bool$(A) = \log_2|\{S \subseteq \overline{A} : \exists X \subseteq A \wedge S = \overline{A} \cap \bigcup_{x \in X} N(x)\}|$.\end{center}Every edge $e \in T$ partitions the vertices $V(G)$ into $(A_e,\overline{A_e})$. The \emph{booleanwidth} of tree decomposition $(T,L)$ is\begin{center}max$_{e \in E(T)}\{$cut-bool$(A_e)\}$\end{center}The \emph{booleanwidth} of a graph $G$ is a minimal booleanwidth of a tree decomposition of $G$.

Parameter.name: Branchwidth
Parameter.note: A branch decomposition of a graph $G$ is a pair $(T,\chi)$. Where:\begin{itemize}\item$T$ is a sub-cubic tree (all vertices have the degree 1 or 3).\item$\chi : A(T) \rightarrow V$ is a bijection, mapping leaves of $T$ to vertices of G. \end{itemize}Any edge $(u,v)$ of the tree divides the tree into two components and dividesthe set of edges of $G$ into two parts $X, E \backslash X$, consisting of edges mapped to theleaves of each component. The width of the edge $(u,v)$ is the connectivity valueof $\lambda_G(X)$. The connectivity value $\lambda_G(X)$ is defined as the number of verticesof $G$ that is incident both with an edge in $X$ and with an edge in $E \backslash X$.The width of the decomposition $(T,\chi)$ is maximum width of its edges.The \emph{branchwidth} of the graph $G$ is the minimum over all branch-decompositionsof $G$.

Parameter.name: Carvingwidth
Parameter.note: Consider a decomposition $(T,\chi)$ of a graph $G$ where $T$ is a sub-cubic tree with $|V(G)|$ leaves and $\chi : A(T) \rightarrow V(G)$ is bijection mapping from the leaves of $T$ into the vertices of $G$. Every edge $e \in E(T)$ of tree $T$, partitions the vertices of the graph $G$ into two partitions $V_e$ and $V \backslash V_e$. Define a \emph{width} of edge of the tree as number of edges of a graph $G$ that have exactly one endpoint in $V_e$ and another endpoint in $V \backslash V_e$,that is\begin{center}$\mathop{width_e} = |\{e = (u,v) \in V(G): u \in V_e \wedge v \in V \backslash V_e\}|$\end{center}Furthermore let the width of the decomposition $(T,\chi)$ be the maximal width over all edges of tree $T$. And finally, the \emph{carving width} of the graph is the minimal width over all decompositions.

Parameter.name: Chromatic Number
Parameter.note: For a graph $G = (V,E)$, let $\phi : V \rightarrow \{1,\ldots,k\}$ be a one-to-one mapping that assigns to each vertex a number (colour). The minimum number of colours needed to label vertices in such a way that no two vertices are connected by an edge is called \emph{chromatic number} of graph.

Parameter.name: Cliquewidth
Parameter.note:
Whether the cliquewidth of the graphs in this class is bounded by a constant k.
The cliquewidth of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
disjoint union,
renaming labels i to label j,
connecting all vertices with label i to all vertices with label j.

Parameter.name: Cutwidth
Parameter.note: The cutwidth of a graph G is the smallest integer k such that the vertices of G can be arranged in a linear layout v1,...,vn in such a way that, for every i = 1,...,n - 1, there are at most k edges with one endpoint in {v1.....vi}. and the other in {vi+1,...,vn}.

Parameter.name: Degeneracy
Parameter.note: Let $G$ be a graph and consider the following algorithm:\begin{itemize}\item Find a vertex $v$ with smallest degree.\item Delete vertex $v$ and its connected edges.\item Repeat as long as the graph is not empty.\end{itemize}Define the \emph{degeneracy} of a graph $G$ as the maximum degree over all deleted vertices.

Parameter.name: Diameter
Parameter.note: The \emph{diameter} of a graph $G$ is the is the shortest path $p$ between two vertices in $G$, where $|p|$ is as large as possible.

Parameter.name: Distance to Clique
Parameter.note: Let~$G$ be a graph. \emph{Distance to Clique} is the minimum number of vertices that have to be deleted from~$G$ in order to obtain a clique.

Parameter.name: Distance to Cluster
Parameter.note: A cluster graph is a graph which does not contain an induced path with three vertices. A distance to cluster of a graph $G$, is the minimal number of vertices to delte, to obtain a cluster graph of $G$.

Parameter.name: Distance to Co-Cluster
Parameter.note: Let~$G$ be a graph. Its \emph{Distance to Co-Cluster} is the minimum number of vertices that have to be deleted to obtain a complement of a cluster graph.

Parameter.name: Distance to Cograph
Parameter.note: A Cograph is a graph $G$, which does not contain an induced path $P$, where $P$ has got four or more vertices. The \emph{distance to cograph} of a graph~$G=(V,E)$ is the minimum size of a set~$X\subseteq V$ such that $G[V\setminus X]$ is a cograph

Parameter.name: Distance to Linear Forest
Parameter.note: A tree $t$ is a graph $G$ where any two vertices are connected by exactly one simple path. A forest $f$ is a graph $G$ which only contains a disjoint union of trees. A linear Forest is a graph $G$, which is a forest with isolated nodes and path graphs.The \emph{distance to linear forest} of a graph $G$ is the size of a smallest set of vertices $S$ with $S \subseteq V$, such that $G[V \backslash S]$ is a linear forest.

Parameter.name: Distance to Outerplanar
Parameter.note: An ouplanar graph is graph which can be drawn in the plane in such way that all vertices belong to the unbounded face of the embedding.A \emph{distance to outplanar} of a graph $G = (V,E)$ is the minumum size of a set $X \subseteq V$, such that $G[V \backslash X]$ is a ouplanar graph.

Parameter.name: Genus
Parameter.note: The genus $g$ of a graph $G$ is the minimum number of handles over all surfaces on which $G$ can be embedded.

Parameter.name: Max-leaf Number
Parameter.note: The \textit{max-leaf number} of a graph $G$ ist the maximum number of leaves in a spanning tree of $G$.

Parameter.name: Maximum Clique
Parameter.note: For a graph $G = (V,E)$ a clique is a subset $X$ of $V$, where $E$ cotains for every two vertices of $X$ an edge. A cilque with the largest number of vertices is a maximum cilque of $G$.

Parameter.name: Maximum Degree
Parameter.note: A maximum degree of a graph $G$ is the degree of a vertex $v$, when its degree is the largest in the graph.

Parameter.name: Maximum Independent Set
Parameter.note: An independent set is a subset of $V$ of the graph $G$. Such that all vertices contained in this subset are not adjacent to each other. The \emph{maximum independent set} is the largest Independent Set of the graph $G$.

Parameter.name: Maximum Induced Matching
Parameter.note: For a graph $G = (V,E)$ let us define an induced matching as an edge subset $M \subseteq E$ that satisfies the following two conditions:\begin{itemize}\item$M$ is matching of the graph $G$ and\itemthere is no edge in $E \backslash M$ connecting any two vertices belonging to edges of the matching $M$.\end{itemize}

Parameter.name: Maximum Matching
Parameter.note: For a graph $G$ let us define matching as subset of disjoint edges (any two edges that do not share an endpoint). Largest matching of a graph $G$ is maximum matching. Hence each edge consist of two different vertices, maxium matching is at most $\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor$. Matching that matched all vertices is called perfect matching

Parameter.name: Minimum Clique Cover
Parameter.note: A \emph{clique cover} of a graph~$G = (V, E)$ is a partition~$P$ of~$V$ such that each part in~$P$ induces a clique in~$G$. The \emph{minimum clique cover} of~$G$ is a clique cover with a minimum number of parts.Note that the clique cover number of a graph is exactly the chromatic number of its complement.

Parameter.name: Minimum Dominating Set
Parameter.note: A dominating set is a subset of vertices $D \subseteq V$ of a graph $G = (V,E)$, such that every vertex not in $D$ is adjacent to at least one member of $D$. a \emph{minimum dominating set} ist the minimal number of vertices, which are needed to create a dominating set.

Parameter.name: Pathwidth
Parameter.note: A path decomposition of a graph $G$ is a pair $(P,X)$ where $P$ is a path, $X = {X_1,X_2,...,X_q}$ is a family of vertex subsets such that:\begin{itemize}\item$\forall(u,v) \in E(G) \exists p : u, v \in X_p$\item$\forall v \in V(G)$ set of vertices ${p|v \in X_p}$ is a connected sub path of $P$.\item$\bigcup_{p \in {1,...,q}} X_p = V(G)$ \end{itemize}The width of a path decomposition $(P,X)$ is $\max(|X_p| - 1)_{p \in {1,...,1}}$. The \emph{pathwidth} of a graph is a minimal width among all possible path decomposition of a graph $G$.

Parameter.name: Rankwidth
Parameter.note: Let cut rank of set $A \subseteq V(G)$ be defined as rank of matrix $M$ where $M$ is an $A \times (V(G) \backslash A)$ matrix over $\mathbb{Z}_2$ s.t.\begin{center}$M_{xy} = \begin{cases}1 & $if $\{x,y\} \in E(G) \\ 0 & $otherwise$\end{cases}$ \newline \newlinecutrk$_{G}(A)$ = rank$(M)$\end{center}The rank decomposition of a graph $G$ is a pair $(T,L)$ where $T$ is a sub-cubic tree and $L$ is a bijection from $V(G)$ to leaves of the tree $T$.The width of the rank-decomposition $(T,L)$ is a maximum width of $e$, over all $e \in E(T)$. For each edge $e \in E(T)$, the width of $e$ is cutrank cutrk$_G(A_e)$, where $(A_e, B_e)$ are partitions of $V(G)$ given by $T \backslash e$. Any edge in a tree $T$ split allleaves $(V(G))$ into two partitions $A_e, B_e$. Rank-width of the graph $G$ is a minimum width of rank-decompositions of $G$.

Parameter.name: Topological Bandwidth
Parameter.note: The Bandwidth bw of a graph $G$ is the maximum "`length"' of an edge in a one dimensional layout of $G$. Formally:\begin{center}\[ml := \min_{i : V \rightarrow \mathbb{N}}\{\max_{\{u,v\}\in E}\{|i(u)-i(v)|\}\mid\text{$i$ is injective}\} \]\end{center}

Parameter.name: Tree Depth
Parameter.note: A tree depth decomposition of a graph $G = (V,E)$ is a rooted tree $T$ with the same vertex set $V$, such that, for every edge $\{u,v\} \in E$, either $u$ is an ancestor of $v$ or $v$ is an ancestor of $u$ in the tree $T$. We define the depth of $T$ as the maximum number of vertices from the root to any leaf. And finally, the \emph{tree depth} of a graph $G$ is minimum depth among all tree depth decompositions.

Parameter.name: Treewidth
Parameter.note:
A tree decomposition of a graph G=(V,E) is a pair ({Xi | i in I}, T = (I, F)) with {Xi | i in I} a family of subsets of V, one for each node in T, and T a tree such that
the union of all Xi, i in I equals V.
for all edges (v,w) in E, there exists i in I, such that v in Xi and w in Xi.
for all v in V: the set of nodes {i in I | v in Xi} forms a subtree of T
The width of the tree decomposition is max |Xi| - 1.
The treewidth of a graph is the minimum width over all possible tree decompositions of the graph.

Parameter.name: Vertex Cover
Parameter.note: Let~$G$ be a graph. Its \emph{vertex cover} number is the minimum number of vertices that have to be deleted in order to obtain an independent set.

parrelation.note: Distance to clique ist the minimal number of vertices to delete from a graph $G$, to obtain that $G$ is clique. a cluster graph is a is a vertex disjoint union of cliques. In order to obtain a cluster graph of $G$ you need at most $\beta$

A clique is the complement of an independent set and an independent set is a co-cluster. Hence, deleting vertices from a graph~$G$ to obtain a clique makes~$G$ a co-cluster in particular. Hence the minimum number of vertices that have to be deleted in order to make~$G$ a co-cluster is at most~$\beta$.

Distance to clique is the minimum number of vertices to delete in order to obtain a clique of a graph $G$. This set is a a clique cover too. Take every vertex of this set as its own part and the clique graph as another part. Hence a minimum clique cover needs at most $\beta$ parts.

A cluster graph is a $P_3$ free graph. A cograph is a $P_4$ free graph. After removing the minimal number of vertices in a graph $G$ to obtain a cograph, it is not ensured that $G$ is $P_3$ free. Maybe more vertices have to be delted. This implies that $\alpha \leq \beta$.

Given is a graph $G$. First step is to create the complement $\overline{G}$ of $G$. If a $G$ is a cograph, than its complement is, by definition, a cograph too. Next step is to create the minimal set of vertices to get a cograph and remove them from $\overline{G}$. the resultig graph does not contain a $P_4$ anymore but maybe still a $P_3$ which is not allowed in a co-cluster. If not $\alpha = \beta$. If there there is still $P_3$, it must be deleted more vertices. This implies $\alpha \leq \beta$.

A cograph is a $P_4$ free graph. To create a cograph of a graph $G$, it must be removed all but three vertices, which contained in the path of the diameter. If $G$ only is the path of the diameter, $\alpha$ can be maximal greater than $beta$ by three, because a $P_3$ is allowed. If $G$ is greater it doesn't change anything. This implies $\alpha \leq \beta + 3$

Be $f(x) = x+1$\\The degree $deg_G$ of all vertices $k$ in the maximum clique is $deg_G(k) = \alpha(G) -1$. Hence $deg_G(k)$ is the smallest possible maximum degree of graph $G$.\\Be $s$ the identifier for all vertices in $G$, which are not in the maximum clique.\\ $deg_G(s) > deg_G(k) \Rightarrow \alpha(G) \leq \beta(G)$ and $deg_G(s)$ is the maximum degree.\\$deg_G(s) \leq deg_G(k) \Rightarrow deg_G(k)$ is the maximum degree.\\ It follows by $f$: $\alpha(G) \leq \beta(G)+1 \Leftrightarrow \alpha(G) \leq f(\beta(G)) \Rightarrow \alpha \leq_{G} \beta$. \\

The maximum independent set is always a dominating set. Because every edge $e$ of the graph $G$ has one ending in the maximum independent set, except of $e$ is part of a clique. If $\beta$ is also the minimum Dominating Set, $\beta = \alpha$. If there is a smaller Dominating Set than $\beta$, it implies $\alpha < \beta$.Both together implies $\alpha \leq \beta$.

A maximum independent contains as many as possible vertices of a graph $G$, which are not adjacent to each other. This means for a minimum clique cover that every vertex of a maximum independent set must be in a different part of the clique partition. Hence a minimum clique cover is always the size of a maximum independent set or bigger.

Let $\beta$ be the diameter of the Graph $G$. The first step to create a minumum domination set is to seperate the diameter in parts $(x,y,z)$ with $x,y,z \in V$, where $x$ is a neighbour of $y$ and $y$ a neighbour of $z$ in the diameter. Every vertex contained in the diameter is only in one part. Next take a vertex $v$ which is neighboured to all three vertices of a part and put $v$ into the minimum dominating set $\alpha$. There can't be a vertex which is neighboured to four vertices of the diameter, because otherwise the path of the diameter would not be the diameter anymore. Hence we need at least one vertex in the minimum dominating set for three vertices of the diameter. This implies that $3 \cdot |\alpha|$ is always upper bounds $\beta$.
Removing the vertices of a vertex cover of a graph $G$ resolves in a graph without edges. This graph is a cluster graph. In order to obtain a cluster graph you need to remove a most $\beta$ vertices.

Since deleting a vertex cover from a graph~$G$ yields an independent set, deleting a vertex cover makes~$G$ a co-cluster. Hence the minimum number of vertices that have to be deleted in order to make~$G$ a co-cluster is at most~$h$.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--split
GraphClass.note: A graph is called 16 if it is 8.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--brittle
GraphClass.note: A graph is 24 if it contains an independent set S such that either every P_4 has a midpoint in S or every P_4 has an endpoint in S.

GraphClass.name: perfectly orderable
GraphClass.note: A vertex order < of G is perfect iff G contains no P_4 abcd with a < b and d < c. A graph is 32 if it admits a perfect order.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Assuming a perfect order is given ref_1424

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Assuming a perfect order is given ref_1424 ref_1382

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is 40 if its vertex set can be partitioned in two subsets, each of which induces a 1216 graph.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--comparability
GraphClass.note: A graph is 48 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o->o<-o->o

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--extendible
GraphClass.note: A graph is 56 if for any subset W of G that contains a P_4 there exists at most one vertex x in G-W such that x forms a P_4 with vertices in W.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--tidy
GraphClass.note:
A partner of a P_4 A in G is a vertex v in G-A such that A+v induces at least two P_4s.
A graph G is 64 if any P_4 has at most one partner.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--laden
GraphClass.note: A graph is 72 if every induced subgraph with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is a 312 graph.

GraphClass.name: brittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 80 iff each induced subgraph H of G contains either a vertex that is not the endpoint of any P_4 of H, or a vertex that is not the midpoint of any P_4 of H.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--laden
GraphClass.note: A graph is 88 if every induced subgraph with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is a 16 graph.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--lite
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 96 if every induced subgraph H of G with at most six vertices that contains more than two induced P_4s is isomorphic to S_3 or to \co{S_3}.

GraphClass.name: weakly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 112 if it is 3480.

A 2-pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has exactly two edges.
A graph is 112 if every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, contains a 2-pair.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--reducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is 120 if every vertex belongs to at most one P_4

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is 144 if every set of five vertices contains at most one induced P_4.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--reducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is 152 if it is 3688.

GraphClass.name: forest--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the nodes of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 160 iff it has the P_4-structure of a forest.

GraphClass.name: HHDS--free
GraphClass.note: A graph is 168 if it is 1856.

GraphClass.name: permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 184 graph iff it has an intersection model consisting of straight lines (one per vertex) between two parallels.

GraphClass.name: alternately orientable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 200 iff it admits an orientation in which no chordless cycle of length at least 4 contains a directed P_3.

GraphClass.name: extended $P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is 208 iff it is 1512.

GraphClass.name: superbrittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 216 iff in every induced subgraph of G no vertex is both a midpoint of an induced P_4 and an endpoint of an induced P_4.

GraphClass.name: Welsh--Powell opposition
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 224 graph if it is an 712 graph for every order satisfying x < y whenever degree(x) >= degree(y).
A graph is a 224 graph if for every induced P_4 abcd: d(b) > d(a) and d(c) > d(d).

GraphClass.name: chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 256 if every cycle of length at least 4 has a chord.

A graph G is 256 if it is the intersection graph of subtrees of a tree T. In particular T can be chosen such that each node of T corresponds to a maximal clique of G and the subtrees Tv consist of precisely those maximal cliques in G that contain v. T is then called the clique tree of G.
A graph G is 256 if every minimal cutset in every induced subgraph of G is a clique.

A vertex v of G is called simplicial in G if N(v) is a clique in G.
The ordering v1...vn of the vertices of G is a perfect elimination order of G if for all i, vi is simplicial in G[v1...vi].
A graph is 256 if it has a perfect elimination order.

GraphClass.name: $\tau_k$--perfect for all $k \ge 2$
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 280 if for every subgraph H we have for the hypergraph H' formed by all trees of diameter at most k>=2 in H that alpha(H') = kappa(H'), where alpha is the packing number (max. vertex set such that every hyperedge contains at most one vertex from the set) and kappa the covering number (min. edge set that contains all vertices).

GraphClass.name: split
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 312 graph if it can be partitioned in an independent set and a clique.

GraphClass.name: 2--interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 320 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 3--interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 328 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 3 intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 2--outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is 336 iff it is 9472 for k=2.

GraphClass.name: planar
GraphClass.note: A graph is 344 if it can be embedded in the plane (drawn with points for vertices and curves for edges) without crossing edges.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: Even when the maximum degree is at most 6 ref_421.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Even when cubic and 3-connected ref_1539.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Even when cubic and cyclically 4-connected ref_1540.

GraphClass.name: 2--threshold
GraphClass.note: A graph is k-threshold iff its threshold dimension is at most k.

GraphClass.name: absolute bipartite retract
GraphClass.note:
A retraction from a graph H to a subgraph G is mapping of V(H) to V(G) such that 1) every node in G is mapped to itself and 2) every edge of H is mapped to an edge of G.
G is an absolute retract if G is a retract of every graph H containing G as an isometric subgraph, provided that \chi(G) = \chi(H), where \chi is the chromatic number.
A graph is an 360 if it is 552 and an absolute retract.

GraphClass.name: half--disk Helly
GraphClass.note:
A half-disk with center u and radius k is the set of nodes v such that d(u,v) <= k and d(u,v) is even, or the set of nodes v such that d(u,v) <= k an d(u,v) is odd.
The half-disk hypergraph of a bipartite graph B has V(B) as vertex set and its half-disks in B as hyperedges.
A 552 graph is 368 if its half-disk hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: dismantlable
GraphClass.note:
K_1 is 392.
G (with at least 2 vertices) is 392 iff there exist vertices y,z such that N[z] \subseteq N[y] (y dominates z) and G(V-z) is 392.

GraphClass.name: modular
GraphClass.note: G is 400 if for every three vertices x,y,z there exists a vertex w that lies on a shortest path between every two of x, y,z; i.e. if every metric triangle has size 0.

GraphClass.name: open--neighbourhood--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The open-neighbourhood hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the open neighbourhood N(v) of all vertices v in V(G) as its hyperedges.
A graph is 408 iff its open-neighbourhood hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: absolute reflexive retract
GraphClass.note:
A retraction of a graph H to a subgraph G is vertex mapping such that every edge of H is mapped to an edge of G and every vertex in G is mapped to itself.
G is an absolute retract if G is a retract of every graph H with chi(G) = chi(H) that contains G as an isometric subgraph, where chi is the chromatic number.
A graph is an 416 if it is 4648 and is an absolute retract.

GraphClass.name: clique--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The clique hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the cliques (maximal complete subgraphs) of G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 432 iff its clique hypergraph has the Helly property.

An extended triangle of G is the subgraph induced by a triangle T together with all vertices that are adjacent to at least two vertices of T.
A graph is 432 iff every of its extended triangles contains a universal vertex.

GraphClass.name: absorbantly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 440 if every induced subgraph H has a minimal dominating (=absorbant) set meeting all maximal cliques in H.

GraphClass.name: perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 448 if for all induced subgraphs H: \chi(H) = \omega(H), where \chi is the chromatic number and \omega is the size of a maximum clique.

GraphClass.name: bip$^*$
GraphClass.note:
A star-cutset C is a cutset that contains a vertex that is adjacent to all other vertices in C.
Every bipartite graph is in 456.
If G or \co{G} has a star-cutset, and G-v is in 456 for all vertices v of G, then G is in 456.

GraphClass.name: trapezoid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 472 graph if it is the intersection graph of trapezoids between two parallel lines.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120; otherwise O(V^2).

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

algo.name: Clique cover
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Timebound valid only when given the modelref_1120.

GraphClass.name: AT--free
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices of a graph form an asteroidal triple if every two of them are connected by a path avoiding the neighbourhood of the third.
A graph is 488 if it does not contain any asteroidal triple.

GraphClass.name: strict quasi--parity
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
G is 520 if each induced subgraph of G is complete or has an even pair.

GraphClass.name: biconvex
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < of X in a bipartite graph B=(X,Y,E) has the adjacency property if for every vertex y in Y, N(y) consists of vertices that are consecutive (an interval) in the ordering < of X.
A bipartite graph (X,Y,E) is 528 if there is an ordering of X and Y that fulfills the adjacency property.

GraphClass.name: convex
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < of X in a bipartite graph B=(X,Y,E) has the adjacency property if for every vertex y in Y, N(y) consists of vertices that are consecutive (an interval) in the ordering < of X.
A bipartite graph (X,Y,E) is 536 if there is an ordering of X or Y that fulfills the adjacency property.

GraphClass.name: bipartable

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Constructing G' and testing bipartiteness can be done polynomially ref_544.

GraphClass.name: bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is 552 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 2 independent sets.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Variant of matching.

GraphClass.name: comparability
GraphClass.note:
The 576 graph of a partial order (V,<=) has node set V and edge xy whenever x<=y or y<=x.
G is a 576 if it is the comparability graph of some poset.
G is a 576 if it transitively orientable, i.e. its edges can be directed such that if a->b and b->c are directed edges, then a->c is a directed edge.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: Gallai
GraphClass.note: A graph is 584 iff it is 1536.

GraphClass.name: Gallai--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The Gallai graph Gallai(G) or \Gamma(G) of a graph G=(V,E) has E as its vertex set and ef is an edge in Gallai(G) if in G e and f are incident (share a vertex) but do not span a triangle. (In other words, e and f induce a P_3 in G.)
cf. 584.
G is 592 if Gallai(G) has no induced odd holes.

GraphClass.name: parity
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 600 graph if for any two induced paths joining the same pair of vertices the path lengths have the same parity (odd or even).

GraphClass.name: chordal bipartite
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph is 632 if each cycle of length at least 6 has a chord.

Let $G=(X,Y,E)$ be a 552 graph. An edge $(x,y)$ is called bisimplicial if $N(x)\cup N(y)$ induces a complete bipartite graph in $G$.
Let $(e_1,\dots,e_m)$ be an ordering of the edges of $G$. Let $G_0=G$ and $G_i = G_{i-1} \setminus e_i$ ($G_i$ is obtained from $G_{i-1}$ by removing the edge $e_i$ but not its endvertices). The ordering $(e_1,\dots,e_m)$ is a perfect edge-without-vertex elimination ordering if $e_i$ is bisimplicial in $G_{i-1}$ for all $1\le i\le m$.
A 552 graph is 632 if it admits a perfect edge-without-vertex elimination ordering.
Let $G=(X,Y,E)$ be a 552 graph. Let $G'$ be the graph obtained from $G$ by adding an edge between every pair of vertices in $X$. A 552 graph $G$ is 632 if $G'$ is 1000.
Note these are not 256 because induced C_4s are allowed. The name 928 is clearer.

GraphClass.name: distance--hereditary
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 640 if it is connected and every induced path is isometric; that is, if the distance function in every induced subgraph of G is the same as in G itself.

A graph G is 640 if it can be construct from a single vertex by the following operations:
Adding a pendant vertex: A new vertex that is adjacent to precisely one existing vertex of the graph.
Creating true twins: For an existing vertex x add a new vertex y with neighbours N[x].
Creating false twins: For an existing vertex x add a new vertex y with neighbours N(x).

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Hammer/Maffray's ref_511 algorithm contained an error that was corrected by Nicolai.ref_809

GraphClass.name: bipartite permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 648 graph, if it is both 552 and a 184 graph.

A strong ordering (<A, <B) of a 552 graph G = (A, B, E) consists of an ordering <A of A and an ordering <B of B, such that for all edges ab, a'b', with a,a' in A and b,b' in B: If a <A a' and b <B b', then ab' and a'b are edges.
A 552 graph is a 648 graph iff it admits a strong ordering.
Note that there is another definition of a strong ordering in 2560.

Let G = (A, B, E) be a 552 graph. An ordering < of A has the adjacency property, if, for every vertex b in B, N(b) consits of vertices that are consecutive in <. An ordering < of A has the enclosure property, if, for every pair b,b' of vertices in B with N(b) \subseteq N(b'), the vertices of N(b')\N(b) appear consecutively in <, implying that b is adjacent to the leftmost or rightmost neighbour of b' in <.
A 552 graph G = (A, B, E) is a 648 graph iff it admits an ordering of A that has the adjacency and enclosure properties.

GraphClass.name: X--star--chordal
GraphClass.note:
Let B=(X,Y,E) be a 552 graph and C a cycle in B. C has an X-star if there is a vertex x in X-C, such that x is adjacent to at least 3 vertices of C.
B is 680 if every chordless cycle of length at least 6 contains an X-star.

GraphClass.name: bipolarizable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 696 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o<-o->o->o

GraphClass.name: opposition
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 712 graph if it has an acyclic orientation that does not contain o->o->o->o or o->o<-o->o has an induced subgraph.
A graph is an 712 graph it has an ordering < such that no P_4 abcd has a<b and c<d.

GraphClass.name: weak bipolarizable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 720 if it is 2808.
A graph is 720 if it is modularly decomposable into chordal graphs.

GraphClass.name: bithreshold
GraphClass.note: G is a 728 graph if it is the edge intersection of two 2624 graphs T,U such that every independent set of G is independent in T or in U.

GraphClass.name: 2--split
GraphClass.note: A graph is 736 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 2 sets, each of which induces a split graph.

GraphClass.name: block
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 744 graph if it is connected and every block (maximal 2-connected component) is a clique.
A graph is a 744 graph if it can be constructed from a 2736 by replacing every edge by a clique of arbitrary size; the cliques have at most one vertex in common.

A graph is a 744 graph if for every four vertices u,v,w,x the larger two of the distance sums
d(u,v)+ d(w,x)
d(u,w)+ d(v,x)
d(u,x)+ d(v,w)
are equal.
A graph is a 744 graph if for every four vertices u,v,w,x the d(u,v)+ d(w,x) <= max( d(u,w)+ d(v,x), d(u,x)+ d(v,w) ).

GraphClass.name: ptolemaic
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is 760 if any four vertices u,v,w,x satisfy the ptolemaic inequality: d(u,v) d(w,x) <= d(u,w) d(v,x) + d(u,x) d(v,w).

GraphClass.name: geodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is 768 if for every pair for vertices the shortest path between them is unique.

GraphClass.name: bounded tolerance
GraphClass.note: A 776 graph is a 1352 graph in which the tolerances are bounded by the length of the corresponding intervals.

GraphClass.name: intersection graphs of parallelograms (squares)
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 784 if it is a 472 graph in which all trapezoids are parallelograms.

GraphClass.name: bridged
GraphClass.note: A bridge of a cycle C is a shortest path in G joining nonconsecutive vertices of C, which is shorter than both the paths of C joining those vertices. G is 792 if every cycle of length at least 4 has a bridge (i.e. the only isometric cycles in G can be of length 3).

GraphClass.name: Helly
GraphClass.note:
A set S of sets Si has the Helly property if for every subset T of S the following hold: if the elements of T pairwise intersect, then the intersection of all elements of T is also non-empty.
The disk hypergraph of G has V(G) has its vertices and the disks D(v,k), v in V(G), k>=1 as its edge sets, where D(v,k) is the set of vertices that have distance at most k to v.
A graph is 840 (or disk Helly) if its disk hypergraph has the Helly property.

Let K(G) be the 1128 graph of G, K0(G) = G and Ki+1(G) = K(Ki(G)). G is called clique-convergent if for some i, Ki+1(G) is isomorphic to Ki(G).
A graph is 840 iff it is 432 and clique-convergent.

GraphClass.name: domination
GraphClass.note:
A vertex ordering v1...vn of G=(V,E) is a domination ordering if for all i there is a j such that vi is dominated by vj in Gi, i.e. N(vi) is a subset of N[vj].
G is a 848 graph if every induced subgraph has a domination elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: quasi--brittle
GraphClass.note:
An edge ab of G is a symmetric wing if there exist vertices c,d,p,q such that both abcd and bapq are P_4s in G.
A graph is 856 if every induced subgraph H contains a vertex incident with no symmetric wing in H and \co{H}.

GraphClass.name: cactus
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 864 if every edge is part of at most one cycle.
They can be constructed from trees by replacing every edge by a cycle of arbitrary size; the cycles have at most one vertex in common.

GraphClass.name: almost tree (1)
GraphClass.note: A graph is an almost tree (k) if every biconnected component has the property that there are at most k edges not in a spanning tree of this biconnected component.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: for fixed k

GraphClass.name: outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is 880 if it has a crossing-free embedding in the plane such that all vertices are on the same face.

GraphClass.name: circle-polygon
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 888 graph if it is the intersection graph of convex polygons inscribed in a circle.

A graph is a 888 graph if there exists a bijection from vertices to sets of connected non-intersecting chords inscribed in a circle such that two vertices are adjacent iff their sets contains at least one pair of intersecting chords.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: A polynomial algorithm was announced in ref_679 but never published. Deciding the smallest k such that all polygons are k-gons is NP-complete ref_1237.

GraphClass.name: good
GraphClass.note:
An ordering < on G is good if for any induced subgraph H of G either the largest vertex of (H,<) is simplicial in H or the smallest vertex of (H,<) is simplicial in \co{H}.
A graph is 896 if it admits a good ordering.

GraphClass.name: slightly triangulated
GraphClass.note: A graph is 912 if it is 3496 and for every induced subgraph H there is a vertex v in H such that the neighbourhood of v in H contains no P_4

GraphClass.name: perfect elimination bipartite
GraphClass.note:
An edge (u,v) in a 552 graph is called bisimplicial if N(u)\cup N(v) induces a biclique in B.
For an edge ordering e1...ek let Si be the set of endpoints of e1...ei.
e1...ek is a perfect edge elimination ordering for a 552 graph B=(V,E) if B[V\Sk] has no edges, and each edge ei is bisimplicial in B[V\Si].
B is 976 if it admits a perfect edge elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension 4 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 992 if it is the 576 of a poset of dimension 4. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extensions of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: strongly chordal
GraphClass.note:
A chord xy in an even cycle C is odd, when the distance in C between x and y is odd.
A graph is 1000 if it is chordal and every cycle of even length at least 6 has an odd chord.

A perfect elimination ordering (see 256) of a graph G is a strong perfect elimination ordering if for all i<j, k<l: if vivk, vivl, vjvk are edges, then vjvl is an edge.
A graph is 1000 if it has a strong perfect elimination ordering.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: The linear time recognition algorithm in ref_1467 was later withdrawn.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: EPT
GraphClass.note: 1024 graphs are the Edge intersection graphs of non-trivial Paths in a Tree.

GraphClass.name: undirected path
GraphClass.note: 1032 graphs are the vertex intersection graphs of undirected paths in an undirected tree.

GraphClass.name: neighbourhood perfect
GraphClass.note:
A neighbourhood cover of a graph $G$ is a set $S$ of vertices such that every edge of $G$ lies in $N[v]$ for some $v\in S$.
The neighbourhood cover number $\kappa_N(G)$ is the smallest cardinality of a neighbourhood cover of $G$.
Two edges of $G$ are said to be neighbourhood independent if there is no vertex $v$ such both edges lie in $N[v]$.
The neighbourhood independence number $\alpha_N(G)$ is the largest number of pairwise neighbourhood independent edges.
A graph is 1048 if for each induced subgraph $$H: $\kappa_N(H) = \alpha_N(H)$.

GraphClass.name: circle
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1056 graph if it is the intersection graph of chords in a circle.

Let the local complement G*v result from G by complementing G[N(v)]. Two graphs are said to be locally equivalent if one results from the other by a series of local complements. Note that this is an equivalence relation. A graph G is a 1056 graph iff no graph locally equivalent to G has an induced subgraph isomorphic to W_5,BW_3 or W_7 ref_140.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: where \alpha is the size of a maximum independent set and d is the density of the graph.

GraphClass.name: circular arc
GraphClass.note: A 1064 graph is the intersection graph of arcs of a circle.
Characterize 1064 graphs by forbidden induced subgraphs ref_1404.
Give an algorithm for finding a certificate for a graph not to be a 1064 graph ref_1404.
Characterize 1064 graphs that admit a model where the arcs have to most two sizes ref_1404.
Characterize circular arc bigraphs (see 1336) ref_1404.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Where l is the minimum number of arcs passing through a given point on the circle.ref_995

GraphClass.name: circular permutation
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1080 if it has an intersection model consisting of paths between two concentric circles, such that no two paths intersect in more than one point.

GraphClass.name: containment graphs of circular arcs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1088 if it has a containment model consisting of arcs on a circle (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding arcs is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: Hamiltonian hereditary
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1104 if every connected induced subgraph has a Hamiltonian path (i.e. a path that visits every vertex exactly once).

GraphClass.name: clique graphs
GraphClass.note:
The clique graph of a graph G is the intersection graph of the maximal complete subgraphs (cliques) in G.
A graph is in 1128 if it is the clique graph of some graph.
A graph G is in 1128 if there is a family of complete subgraphs of G that covers all edges of G and has the Helly property (see 840).

GraphClass.name: clique separable
GraphClass.note:
Call a graph primitive if it has no clique cutset. Then:
A graph G is 1136 if every primitive induced subgraph of G is either complete k-partite or can be partitioned into a connected bipartite graph A and a clique B such that there is a join between A and B.

GraphClass.name: preperfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x predominates a vertex y if either they are adjacent and every maximal clique containing y also contains x, or they are non-adjacent and every maximal independent set containing x also contains y.
A graph is 1144 (or predomination perfect) if every induced subgraph has a predominating vertex.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: See also ref_425.

GraphClass.name: absolutely perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1168 if every induced subgraph H has an independent set meeting all mininal vertex sets of H that are dominating \co{H}.
A graph is a 1176 if it is the intersection graph of curves from a line to a parallel line.

GraphClass.name: quasi--parity
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
A graph is 1200 if for every induced subgraph H, either H or \co{H} has an even pair.

GraphClass.name: cograph
GraphClass.note:
G is a 1208 (short for complement-reducible graph) if one of the following equivalent conditions hold:
G can be constructed from isolated vertices by disjoint union and join operations.
G is the disjoint union of 640 graphs with diameter at most 2.
in every induced subgraph H of G, the intersection of any maximal clique and any maximal independent set contains precisely one vertex.
Every nontrivial induced subgraph of G has at least one pair of twins (two vertices with the same neighbourhoods).
The complement of every nontrivial connected induced subgraph of G is disconnected.
Every connected induced subgraph of G has diameter at most 2.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of series--parallel posets
GraphClass.note:
The parallel composition of two posets is their disjoint union. The series composition P*Q of two posets P and Q has as elements the union of the elements of P and Q, and u<v in P*Q if either u<v in P or u<v in Q or u is in P and v is in Q (i.e. every element in P is smaller than every element in Q).
A series-parallel poset can be composed from single elements by repeated application of series and/or parallel composition.

GraphClass.name: cograph contraction
GraphClass.note: A 1232 is formed from a 1208 by contracting some disjoint independent sets and then creating a join between all contracted vertices.
A graph G is a 1232 iff it has a clique Q such that every induced P_4 in G has a midpoint in Q and every induced P_5 in the complement of G has both endpoints in Q.

GraphClass.name: tree--perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 1240 iff it has the P_4-structure of a 2736.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of semiorders
comparability graphs of dimension 3 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1280 if it is the 576 graph of a poset of dimension 3. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extension of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: containment graph of circles
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1288 if it has a containment model consisting of circles (disks) in 2 dimensional space (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding circles is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: containment graphs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1304 if it has a model consisting of objects space such that two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding objects is contained in the other one.

GraphClass.name: superperfect
GraphClass.note:
Let w be a non-negative weighting of the vertices of a graph G. An interval coloring of (G,w) maps each vertex v onto an open interval Iv with length w(v) of the real line, such that adjacent vertices are mapped to disjoint intervals.The interval coloring number \chiint(G,w) is the minimum length of the union of all Iv's over all interval colorings.
A graph is 1312 if for every non-negative weighting w \chiint(G,w) = \omega(G,w), where \omega is the maximum clique weight.

GraphClass.name: interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph B=(X,Y,E) is an 1336 if every vertex can be assigned an interval on the real line such that for all x \in X and y \in Y: xy \in E iff the corresponding intervals intersect.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
A 552 graph G is an 1336 if there exists a set of consecutively orderable complete bipartite graphs that cover the edges of G.
Characterize 1336 graphs by forbidden induced subgraphs ref_1405.

GraphClass.name: tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1352 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a tolerance tv such that x and y are adjacent iff |Ix \cap Iy| >= min{tx, ty}.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: ref_1497 This is optimal

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: ref_1498 This is optimal

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: ref_1498 This is optimal

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1384 if it has Dilworth number 3.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1392 if it has Dilworth number 4.

GraphClass.name: directed path
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1400 if it has an intersection model consisting of directed paths in a rooted directed tree.

Let G = (V,E) be a graph and K be the set of all maximal cliques of G. For each vertex v of G, let Kv be the set of cliques of K containing v. Then G is a 1400 iff there exists a rooted directed tree T with the vertex set K, such that for every v in V, the subtree of T induced on Kv is a directed path in T.

GraphClass.name: cop--win
GraphClass.note:
An ordering v1...vn of the vertices of a graph is a cop-win ordering (or dismantling ordering) if for each i<n there is a j>i such that Ni[vi] \subseteq Ni[vj].
A graph is 1408 if it has a cop-win ordering.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph; from ref_1643 and ref_1644

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--crossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1416 if every cycle of at least 5 nodes has at least 2 crossing chords. Two chords uv, xy are crossing if the order in C of the endpoints is (u,x,v,y).

GraphClass.name: domino
GraphClass.note: G is a 1432 graph if every vertex of G is contained in at most two maximal cliques of G.

GraphClass.name: doubly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1448 if it is 1464.

GraphClass.name: Helly chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1472 if it is 1632.

GraphClass.name: dually chordal
GraphClass.note:
A vertex u in N[v] is a maximum neighbour of v if for all w in N[v]: N[w] \subseteq N[u]. A vertex ordering v1...vn is a maximumneighbourhood ordering if for each i<n vi has a maximum neighbour in Gi.
A graph is 1480 if it has a maximum neighbourhood ordering.
A graph G is 1480 iff there is a spanning tree T of G, such that every maximal clique of G induces a subtree in T.

A disk D(v,k) in G is the set of vertices that have distance at most k to v.
A graph G is 1480 iff there is a spanning tree T of G, such that every disk of G induces a subtree in T.

GraphClass.name: homogeneously orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v of G is h-extremal if D2(v) contains a dominating set that is proper homogeneous (a non-trivial module) in G.
A vertex ordering v1,..,vn is a homogeneous elimination ordering if for every i, vi is h-extremal in G[vi...vn].
G is 1496 if it has homogeneous elimination ordering.

GraphClass.name: semi--$P_4$--sparse
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1520 iff it is 2464 free.

GraphClass.name: $i$--triangulated
GraphClass.note: A synonym for 584.

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--noncrossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1536 if every cycle of odd length at least 5 has at least 2 noncrossing chords.

GraphClass.name: Meyniel
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1552 if every cycle of odd length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

An even pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has an even number of edges.
A graph is 1552 if for every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, all vertices are part of an even pair in H.

GraphClass.name: bigeodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1560 if every pair of vertices has at most 2 paths of minimum length between them.

GraphClass.name: weakly geodetic
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1568 if for every pair of vertices of distance 2 there is a unique common neighbour of them.

GraphClass.name: quasitriangulated
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1576 if it has an elimination ordering v1,..,vn such that vi is simplicial in Gi or in \overline{Gi}.

A graph is latticed if every vertex belongs to some cycle and some co-cycle, both of length at least 4.
A graph G is 1576 if no induced subgraph of G is latticed.

GraphClass.name: Halin
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1584 graph if it is formed by embedding a 2736 having no degree-2 vertices in the plane and connecting its leaves by a cycle that crosses none of its edges.

GraphClass.name: partial 3--tree
GraphClass.note: See 4760

GraphClass.name: 3--Helly
GraphClass.note: G is a 1608 graph if every 3 pairwise intersecting disks have a non-empty intersection.

GraphClass.name: neighbourhood--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The neighbourhood hypergraph of G has V(G) has its vertices and the closed neighbourhoods N[v], v in V(G), as its edge sets.
A graph is 1616 if its neighbourhood hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--modular
GraphClass.note: G is 1624 if every metric triangle has size at most 1.

GraphClass.name: Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note: G is a 1640 graph if there is a circular arc representation of G that satisfies the Helly property.
G is a 1640 graph if it admits a clique matrix (cliques in rows, vertices in columns) that has the circular consecutive one property for columns.

An obstacle is a graph H, containing a clique Q on at least 3 vertices, admitting a circular ordering v1..vq on its vertices, where each edge vivi+1 satisfies
there is a vertex wi outside Q such that wi is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi, vi+1; or
there is an edge uizi outside Q such that li is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi and zi is adjacent to all vertices in Q except for vi+1.
G is a 1640 graph if it is a 1064 graph and does not contain an obstacle as an induced subgraph.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: a(x,y) is the (very slowly growing) functional inverse of the Ackermann function

GraphClass.name: median
GraphClass.note: Let $I(x,y)$ be the set of all vertices on all shortest paths between $x$ and $y$. G is 1688 if for all vertices $x,y,z$: $I(x,y) \cap I(x,z) \cap I(y,z) = 1$.

GraphClass.name: $N^*$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
Define a preorder <v of the nodes of a graph by: x<vy iff N'(x) \subseteq N[y], where N'(x) is the set of nodes at distance 1 or 2 from x.
A graph is 1720 if every ordering v1,...,vn such that i < j iff vi >v vj and not vj >v vi is a perfect order.

GraphClass.name: murky
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1744 if it is 2184.

GraphClass.name: $V$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
An ordering <o of the nodes of a graph is a vicinal preoder if for all vertices x, y: x<oy iff N(x) \subseteq N[y].
A graph is 1760 if every ordering v1,...,vn such that i < j iff vi >o vj and not vj >o vi is a perfect order.

GraphClass.name: isometric--HH--free
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1768 it doesn't contain a house or hole as isometric subgraph.

GraphClass.name: weakly modular
GraphClass.note:
The triangle condition: For every three vertices u,v,w with 1 = d(v,w) < d(u,v) = d(u,w), there is a common neighour x of v and w such that d(u,x) = d(u,v) + 1.
The quadrangle condition: For every four vertices, u,v,w,z with d(v,z) = d(w,z) = 1 and d(u,v) = d(u,w) = d(u,z) - 1, there is a common neighbour x of v and w such that d(u,x) = d(u,v) - 1.
A graph is 1776 if its distance metric fulfills the triangle and quadrangle conditions.

The interval I(u,v) contains all vertices that lie on a shortest path from u to v. Three vertices u,v,w form a metric triangle if the interval I(u,v), I(v,w) and I(w,u) pairwise intersect only in the common end vertices.
A graph is 1776 if for every metric triangle u,v,w all vertices of I(v,w) are at the same distance k=d(u,v) from u.

GraphClass.name: maxibrittle
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 1800 if every induced subgraph of G has no P_4 having a vertex of maximum degree as an endpoint and no P_4 having a vertex of minimum degree as an endpoint.

GraphClass.name: HH--free
GraphClass.note:
A 2-pair in a graph is a pair of non-adjacent vertices x, y such that every chordless path has exactly two edges.
A graph is 1824 if for every connected induced subgraph H that is not a complete graph, all vertices are part of a 2-pair in H.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: a(x,y) is the (very slowly growing) functional inverse of the Ackermann function

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 1840 if every cycle of length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 1872 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of intervals on a straight line.

Even though the weighted clique and colourability problems are polynomial time solvable on both 1872 and 1256 graphs, the weighted clique partitioning problem [PCliqW] is NP-hard for 1872 graphs ref_1484.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: ref_1532 if the interval representation is given

algo.name: Hamiltonian path
algo.note: ref_1532 if the interval representation is given

GraphClass.name: boxicity 1
GraphClass.note: A graph has 1888 if it has an intersection model consisting of axis-parallel boxes in 1-dimensional space.

GraphClass.name: boxicity 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has 1912 if it has an intersection model consisting of axis-parallel boxes (i.e. rectangles) in 2-dimensional space.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given.

GraphClass.name: PI
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1920 (Point-Interval) graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangle between two lines L and M such that every triangle a,b,c has a on L and bc on M.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Recognition is in NP ref_1496.

GraphClass.name: threshold signed
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 1968 if there are positive real numbers S,T (the thresholds) and for every vertex v there is a real weight av <=S,T such that: vw is an edge iff either |av + aw| >= S or |av - aw| >= T.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: From 1872 and 1256.

GraphClass.name: line
GraphClass.note:
The line graph (E,E') of G = (V,E) has edges (e,f) if e\cap f isn't empty in G.
A graph is a 1992 graph if it is the line graph of some graph.
A graph G is a 1992 graph if the edges of G can be partitioned into maximal complete subgraphs such that no vertex lies in more than two of the subgraphs.

A triangle T of a graph G is called odd if there is a vertex of G that is adjacent to an odd number of vertices of T.
A graph G is a 1992 graph if G is 496 and if two odd triangles have a common edge, then the subgraph induced by their vertices is a K_4.

GraphClass.name: locally perfect
GraphClass.note:
Let C be a colouring of of the vertices G such that no two neighbouring vertices have the same colour. Let F(v,C) be the number of colours appearing in N(v). C is locally perfect if for every vertex v: F(v,C) = \omega(N(v)), where \omega(S) is the size of a maximum clique in S.
A graph is 2032 if every induced subgraph has a locally perfect colouring.

GraphClass.name: matrogenic
GraphClass.note: A set W of vertices of G = (V,E) is threshold independent if G[W] is a 2624 graph. Let IV denote the family of threshold independent vertex sets. Then G is 2040 if (V,IV) is a matroid.

GraphClass.name: unigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2048 if it is determined by its degree sequence up to isomorphism.

GraphClass.name: matroidal
GraphClass.note: A set F of edges of G = (V,E) is threshold independent if G[F] is a 2624 graph. Let IE denote the family of threshold independent edge sets. Then G is 2056 if (E,IE) is a matroid.

GraphClass.name: Matula perfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 2072 if every vertex ordering < such that
x < y whenever degH(x) >= degH(y) and H is the subgraph induced by all z such that z <= y
is perfect.

GraphClass.name: Hilbertian
GraphClass.note: Let I(x,y) be the set of all vertices on all shortest paths between x and y. G is 2088 if for all vertices x,y,z: I(x,y) contains a unique vertex nearest to z.

GraphClass.name: pseudo--median
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2096 if for every triple of vertices u,v,w either there exists a unique vertex on shortest paths between each pair of them (if their mutual distances sum up to an even number), or there exists a unique triangle whose edges lie on a shortest paths between the three pairs of u,v,w (if the distance sum is odd).
A graph is 2096 if the following condition holds for all triples of vertices u,v,w: if 1<=d(v,w)<=2 and d(u,v) = d(u,w) = k>=2 then there is a unique vertex x adjacent to v and w with d(u,x)=k-1.

GraphClass.name: quasi--median
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2104 if every interval in G induces a 1688 graph and for any three vertices u,v,w: I(u,v) \cap I(u,w) = {u} implies that d(v,w) >= max( d(u,v), d(u,w) ).

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2112 if every odd cycle of length at least 5 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: very strongly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2120 if for every induced subgraph H, every vertex of H belongs to an independent set of H meeting all maximal cliques of H.

GraphClass.name: perfectly contractile
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices form an even pair if all chordless paths between them have even length.
A graph is 2128 if for all induced subgraphs H there is a sequence H=H0,...,Hk such that Hk is a clique and Hi+1 is obtained from Hi by contracting an even pair.

GraphClass.name: strongly perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2136 if every induced subgraph H has an independent set meeting all maximal cliques of H.

GraphClass.name: minimally imperfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 2160 if it is not 448 and every induced subgraph is 448.
These are precisely the odd (anti)-holes ref_1128.

GraphClass.name: partitionable
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 2168 if there are a,w such that G has aw+1 vertices and for each vertex v of G: G-v admits a partition into a cliques of size w and a partition into w independent sets of size a.

GraphClass.name: multitolerance
GraphClass.note: For an interval I = [l,r] on the real line and lt,rt \in I, define I(lt,rt) as the set of all intervals [l+(rt-l)x, lt+(r-lt)x] for all 0<=x<=1. The set of tolerance intervals for I is either I(lt,rt) or the (infinite) real line. A graph is a 2176 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a set Tv of tolerance intervals such that x and y are adjacent iff either there is a t in Tx such that t \subseteq Iy or there is a t in Ty such that t \subseteq Ix.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: ref_1497 This is optimal

GraphClass.name: Berge
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2192 if it is 4776.

GraphClass.name: series--parallel
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a multigraph. Two edge e, f in G are confluent if there are no cycles C, D in G, such that C meets e and f in the same direction, but D meets e and f in the opposite direction.
G is 2200 if every pair of edges is confluent.

The S operation entails subdividing an edge by a new vertex (replacing an edge by two edges in series).
The P operation entails replacing an edge by two edges in parallel.
Let G be a multigraph. G is 2200 if its 2-connected components can be generated from a loop with S and P operations.

The S operation entails deleting a vertex of degree 2 and adding a new edge between its neighbours.
The P operation entails deleting an edge parallel to another edge.
Let G be a multigraph. G is 2200 if its 2-connected components can be reduced to a loop with S and P operations.

GraphClass.name: (5,2)--odd--crossing--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2208 if every odd cycle C of length at least 5 has at least 2 crossing chords. Two chords uv, xy are crossing if the order in C of the endpoints is (u,x,v,y).

GraphClass.name: unbreakable
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 2216 if neither G nor its complement have a star-cutset. A star-cutset is a cutset that contains a vertex that is adjacent to all other vertices of the cutset.
A graph G is 2224 iff each component of G is 552 or complete multipartite.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: By the characterization.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: By the characterization.

GraphClass.name: ${\cal C}(G)$--perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 2232 if for every subgraph H we have for the hypergraph H' formed by all cliques in H that alpha(H') = kappa(H'), where alpha is the packing number (max. vertex set such that every hyperedge contains at most one vertex from the set) and kappa the covering number (min. edge set that contains all vertices).

GraphClass.name: perfectly 1--transversable
GraphClass.note:
An induced subgraph H of G is an i-transversal if \omega(H)=i and \omega(G-H) = \omega(G)-i, where \omega is the maximum clique size.
A graph G is perfectly i-transversable if each induced subgraph H of G admits a min(\omega(H), i)-transversal of H.

GraphClass.name: kernel solvable
GraphClass.note:
A superorientation of a graph G=(V,E) is an orientation of all edges uv, where both u->v and v->u may occur simultaneously.
Let D=(V,A) be a (super)oriented graph. S\subseteq V is a kernel of D if it is both independent, i.e. no vertex of S has a successor in S, and absorbant, i.e. every vertex outside S has a successor in S.
A graph D is 2248 if for every superorientation D of G for which every clique has a kernel, D itself has a kernel.

GraphClass.name: normal
GraphClass.note:
A graph G is 2256 if there exists families C and S of sets of vertices such that
for all c in C and s in S: c\cap s is non-empty,
every member of C induces a clique in G and every member of S induces an independent set in G,
every vertex of G is obtainable as an intersection of members of C and S.

GraphClass.name: circle graph with equator
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2280 if it is a 1056 that admits an additional chord (the equator) that intersects every other chord.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension 2 posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2296 if it is the 576 of a poset of dimension 2 (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extension of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: containment graph of intervals
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2304 if it has a containment model consisting of intervals on a line (i.e. two vertices are adjacent if one of the corresponding intervals is contained in the other one).

GraphClass.name: PI$^*$
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2320 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangles between two lines.

GraphClass.name: genus 0
GraphClass.note: The genus of a graph is the smallest genus of a surface in which G can be embedded without crossings.

GraphClass.name: ${\cal P}_3$--perfect
GraphClass.note:
Let chi'(G) be the minimum size of a partition of G into K_3-free subgraphs and let omega'(G) be the maximum of chi'(C) over all cliques C of G.
A graph is 2336 if for each induced subgraph H of G: chi'(H) = omega'(H).

GraphClass.name: toroidal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2344 if it can be embedded in the torus without crossings.

GraphClass.name: power--chordal
GraphClass.note:
The k-th power of a graph G is a graph on the same vertex set as G, where a pair of vertices is connected by an edge if they have distance at most k in G.
A graph is 2352 if all its powers are 256.

GraphClass.name: clique--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2368 if the 1992 graph of its 1128 graph is chordal.

GraphClass.name: proper circular arc
GraphClass.note: A 2376 graph is a 1064 graph that has an intersection model in which no arc properly contains another.

GraphClass.name: proper interval
GraphClass.note: A 2384 graph is an 1872 graph that has an intersection model in which no interval properly contains another.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: ref_1531 if the interval representation is given

GraphClass.name: unit interval
GraphClass.note: A 2392 graph is an 1872 graph that has an intersection model in which every interval has unit length.

GraphClass.name: astral triple--free
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices are an astral triple if for every pair of them there is a path connecting the two vertices that contains neither the third vertex nor two consecutive vertices that are neighbours of the third vertex.
A graph is 2416 if it does not contain an astral triple.

GraphClass.name: unit circular arc
GraphClass.note: A 2432 graph is a 1064 graph that has an intersection model in which every arc has unit length.

GraphClass.name: proper tolerance
GraphClass.note: A 2440 is a 1352 graph in which no interval contains another interval.

GraphClass.name: $K_4$--minor--free
GraphClass.note:
G is a minor of H if G can be obtained from H be a series of vertex deletions, edge deletions and/or edge contractions (replacing two adjacent vertices u,v by a vertex that is adjacent to all neighbours of u or v).
A graph G is 2472 if K_4 isn't a minor of G.

GraphClass.name: short--chorded
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2488 if every odd hole has a short chord, i.e. a chord joining two vertices of distance 2 in the cycle.

GraphClass.name: polar
GraphClass.note: A 2512 graph is a graph G whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that A induces a subgraph of the complement of G and B induces a subgraph of G all of whose connected components are complete graphs.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: NP-Complete for any fixed >=2 maximum cardinality of a connected component of G(B).

GraphClass.name: strict 2--threshold
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2528 graph if its edge-set can be partitioned into two threshold graphs A and B such that every triangle of G is a triangle of A or a triangle of B.

GraphClass.name: generalized strongly chordal
GraphClass.note: A synonym for 2560.

GraphClass.name: strongly orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex ordering of a graph G is a strong ordering if for all i<j, k<l: if vivk, vivl, vjvk are edges, then vjvl is an edge.
Note that a strong ordering is not necessarily a perfect elimination ordering.
A graph is 2560 if it admits a strong ordering.

GraphClass.name: strong tree--cograph
GraphClass.note: A 2584 is a 2568 if the 2584s used in the disjoint union are pairwise nonisomorphic.

GraphClass.name: Birkhoff
GraphClass.note: A graph with adjacency matrix A is a 2576 if every double stochastic matrix X for which XAX-1 = A is a convex sum of automorphisms of A.

GraphClass.name: tree--cograph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2584 if it can be constructed from trees by disjoint union and complement operations.

algo.name: Cliquewidth decomposition
algo.note: From the decomposition tree.

GraphClass.name: superfragile
GraphClass.note:
Elimination rule 1: if x does not appear as an endpoint in an induced P_3 then x may be removed.
Elimination rule 2: if x does not appear as a midpoint in an induced P_3 then x may be removed.
A graph is 2600 if it has an elimination order w.r.t. the above rules, such that at every stage every vertex is eligible for elimination.
A graph G is 2600 iff in every induced subgraph of G no vertex is both a midpoint of an induced P_3 and an endpoint of an induced P_3.

GraphClass.name: trivially perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2616 if for every induced subgraph H, alpha(H) = |C(H)|, where alpha is the size of the largest independent set and C is the set of all maximal cliques.

GraphClass.name: threshold
GraphClass.note:
The following are equivalent definitions of the threshold dimension of a graph:
Let G be a graph with nodes v1...vn. The characteristic vector x of X\subseteq V has xi = 1 if vi in X and 0 otherwise. The treshold dimension \theta(G) if the minimum number k of linear inequalities aj1x1 + ... + ajnxn <= tj (1<=j<= k) such that X is an independent set iff its characteristic vector x satisfies this system of inequalities.
The treshold dimension of a graph (V,E) is the minimum number k of threshold graphs (V,Ei) such that E equals the union of all Ei.
A graph is a 2624 graph iff its threshold dimension is at most 1.
A graph is a 2624 graph if there is a real number S (the threshold) and for every vertex v there is a real weight av such that: vw is an edge iff av + aw >= S.
A graph is a 2624 graph if it can constructed from the empty graph by repeatedly adding either an isolated vertex or a dominating vertex.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 1
GraphClass.note:
Two vertices x and y are said to be comparable if either N(y) \subseteq N[x] or N(x) \subseteq N[y].
The Dilworth number of a graph is the largest number of pairwise incomparable vertices of the graph.
A graph is a 2640 if it has Dilworth number 1.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of threshold orders
GraphClass.note: A threshold order is a partial order P on a set V, with weightfunction w on V and a threshold t such that C is a maximal chain of P iff the sum of the weights of the nodes in C is at most t.

GraphClass.name: Dilworth 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2680 if it has Dilworth number 2.

GraphClass.name: threshold tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph (V,E) is a 2688 is there are real-valued functions w and t on V such that xy is an edge iff w(x)+w(y) >= min(t(x), t(y)).
A graph is a 2688 if there are real-valued weight functions a and b on V such that xy is an edge iff a(x) <= b(y) and a(y) <= b(x).

GraphClass.name: genus 1
GraphClass.note: The genus of a graph is the smallest genus of a surface in which G can be embedded without crossings.

GraphClass.name: bounded multitolerance
GraphClass.note: A 2176 graph is a 2728 graph if it doesn't contain any vertex with the real line as its set of tolerance intervals.

GraphClass.name: tree
GraphClass.note: A 2736 is a connected acyclic graph. A disconnect acyclic graph (i.e. every connected component is a tree) is a forest.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: Obvious.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of arborescence orders
GraphClass.note: A partial order (V,<) is an arborescence order if for all x in V the set {y|y<x} is linearly ordered.

GraphClass.name: intersection graph of nested intervals
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 2776 if it is an 1872 graph with a model in which no interval partially overlaps another interval.

GraphClass.name: $p$--connected
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 2784 if for every partition of V(G) into X and Y there is a crossing P_4 between X and Y, i.e. a P_4 containing vertices from both X and Y.

A p-chain connecting two vertices x and y is a sequence of distinct vertices v1...vk such that x = v1, y = vk and for all i <= k-3 the set {vi, vi+1, vi+2, vi+3} induces a P_4.
A graph G is 2784 if every pair of vertices is connected by a p-chain.

GraphClass.name: unit tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 2792 if it is a 1352 in which every interval is of unit length.

GraphClass.name: Welsh--Powell perfect
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 2800 if every vertex ordering < such that
x < y whenever degG(x) >= degG(y)
is perfect.

GraphClass.name: wing--triangulated
GraphClass.note:
For a graph $G$ the graph $W(G)$ having all edges of $G$ as its vertices, two edges of $G$ being adjacent in $W(G)$ if they are the nonincident edges (called wings) of an induced path on four vertices in $G$, is called the wing-graph of G.
A graph G is 2816 if W(G) is 7560.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.note: Every connected component of a 2856 graph is 2968 or complete multipartite.

GraphClass.name: (6,1)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2920 if every cycle of length at least 6 has at least 1 chord.

GraphClass.name: X--conformal
GraphClass.note: Let B=(X,Y,E) be a bipartite graph. B is 2944 if for every S $\subseteq$ Y with the property that all nodes of S have pairwise distance 2, there is a node x in X such that S $\subseteq$ N(x).

GraphClass.name: X--chordal
GraphClass.note: Let B=(X,Y,E) be a bipartite graph. B is 2952 if for cycle C in B of length at least 8, there is a node x in X that is adjacent to at leeast two nodes in C whose distance in C is at least 4 (that is, x is a bridge node).

GraphClass.name: (6,2)--chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 2960 if every cycle of length at least 6 has at least 2 chords.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 3016 if it is the 576 of a poset of interval dimension 2.
For connected graphs, this class is equivalent to 3032. In ref_68 equivalence is claimed falsely for unconnected graphs as well, see the note at ref_68.

GraphClass.name: thick tree
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 3064 if it is 256 and every two separators are either equal or disjoint.

GraphClass.name: AC
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 3072 graph if it is chordal and every vertex belong to at most 2 maximal cliques.
Largest subclass of sun-free that is closed under complementation

GraphClass.name: unit disk
GraphClass.note: A 3112 graph is a 3312 graph with an intersection model consisting of disks of unit size.
Many problems that are NP-complete in general remain NP-complete on this class. See e.g. ref_229.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Assuming the positions of the disks are given ref_229.

GraphClass.name: interval filament
GraphClass.note:
Let I be a collection of intervals on a line L. In the plane above L, construct to each interval i\in I a curve ci connecting its two endpoints, such that ci remains within the limits of i. The curves ci are called interval filaments.
A graph is an 3120 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of interval filaments.
A graph is an 3120 if it is the intersection graph of continuous non-negative functions defined on closed intervals with zero-values on their endpoints.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Finite forbidden subgraph characterization.

GraphClass.note: Every connected 3168 graph has a dominating clique or a dominating P_3 ref_42.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: trivial

GraphClass.name: planar of maximum degree 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3296 if it is 344 and every vertex has degree at most 3.

GraphClass.name: disk
GraphClass.note: A 3312 graph is the intersection graph of disks in two-dimensional space.

GraphClass.name: well covered
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3320 if every maximal independent set is a maximum independent set.

algo.name: Independent set
