algo.note: trivial

GraphClass.name: visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let P be a simple polygon in standard position. The visibility graph of P has vertices corresponding to the extreme points of P. Two vertices are adjacent if either they are consecutive extreme points of P, or the line between them is entirely contained in P.
A graph is a 3352 graph if it is the visibility graph of some polygon.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Because for all v: G[\co{N}(v)] is P_4-free

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Algorithm for (P_5,K_{m,m})-free (fixed m) ref_1118

GraphClass.name: subtree overlap
GraphClass.note: A graph G=(V,E) is a 3472 if every node x,y in V can be assigned a subtree of a tree I such that x and y are adjacent iff their corresponding subtrees overlap (i.e. the subtrees intersect, but neither one contains the other one).

GraphClass.name: partial grid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 3520 iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a 3712.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643

GraphClass.name: bipartite chain
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 3536 graph iff it is 552 and for each color class the neighbourhoods of the nodes in that color class can be ordered linearly w.r.t. inclusion (subset or equal).
Sometimes called 3616.

GraphClass.name: bi-cograph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 3552 iff it is a 552 graph that can be reduced to isolated vertices by recursively bi-complementing the edge set of all connected bipartite subgraphs, where the bi-complement of (X,Y,E) is (X,Y, X\times Y - E).

GraphClass.name: bisplit
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3616 iff it can be partitioned in an independent set and a bi-clique.
Attention: 3536 graphs are sometimes also called 3616.

GraphClass.name: tripartite
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3624 iff it can be partitioned in 3 independent sets.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: Trivial. Note that finding an actual colour assignment is NP-complete ref_1425.

GraphClass.name: weak bisplit
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 3656 iff it has an independent set X such that every connected component of G-X is a biclique.
Attention: 3568 graphs are sometimes also called 3656.

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--simplicial
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3672 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is either of the type: o<-o->o->o or of the type o->o->o->o

GraphClass.name: $P_4$--indifference
GraphClass.note: A graph is 3680 if it admits an acyclic orientation in which each induced P_4 is of the type: o->o->o->o

GraphClass.name: k-polygon
GraphClass.note: A 3696 graph is the intersection graph of chords in a k-polygon.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Assuming the input is a 1056 graph.ref_353

GraphClass.name: grid
GraphClass.note: An n\times m 3712 is the cartesian product of P_n and P_m.

algo.name: Treewidth
algo.note: The treewidth of a n x m grid is min(n, m) ref_1411

GraphClass.name: split-perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 3720 iff it has the P_4-structure of a 312 graph.

algo.name: Domination
algo.note: Assuming a square embedding of the graph is given; finding this is an open problem.

GraphClass.name: 2-subdivision
GraphClass.note:
A 2-subdivision of a graph results from inserting 2 new vertices in every edge, that is from replacing each edge $uv$ with a P_4 $uxyv$.
A graph is a 3776 if it is the 2-subdivision of some graph.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: From Poljak'sref_1111 construction (which is a 2-subdivision). See also ref_453

GraphClass.note: Let G be 3888 and U,U' a bipartition of its vertex set in two cliques. Then G is 3896 iff the edges between U and U' can be bi-coloured in such a way that the edges of any induced C_4 have distinct colours.

Let G be a graph and let G* be the graph with V(G*) = E(G) and two vertices of G* are adjacent precisely when the endpoints of the corresponding edges of G induce a C_4 in G.
G is 3896 iff both the complement of G and G* are 552.
If a graph is in 3896, then it has a circular arc model with two points on the circle, such that every arc contains at least one of them.

GraphClass.name: (q,t)
GraphClass.note: G is a 3904 if every set of at most q vertices induces at most t distinct P_4's.

GraphClass.name: (p,q)-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4000 iff it can be partitioned in p cliques and q independent sets.

GraphClass.name: partner-limited
GraphClass.note:
A partner of a P_4 A in G is a vertex v in G-A such that A+v induces at least two P_4s.
A graph G is 4032 if any P_4 has at most two partners.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension 2, height 1
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 4176 if it is the 576 of a poset of interval dimension 2, height 1.

GraphClass.name: difference
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 4192 if every vertex vi can be assigned a real number ai and there exists a positive real number T such that (a) |ai| < T for all i and (b) (vi, vj) in E <=> |ai-aj| >= T.
A 4200 graph consists of disjoint cycles and paths.

GraphClass.name: F_n grid
GraphClass.note: An 4208 is a modification of an $n\times n$ 3712 which has unbounded cliquewidth. See ref_1176 for a precise definition; as an example, $F_4$ looks like this:

GraphClass.name: H_{n,q} grid
GraphClass.note: An 4216 with $n\ge 4$ is a modification of an $n\times n$ 3712 which has unbounded cliquewidth for any fixed $q\ge 2$. See ref_1176 for a precise definition; as an example, $H_{4,2}$ looks like this:

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: Contains the 3776 of graphs of max. degree 3. See also 3296.

GraphClass.name: Raspail
GraphClass.note: Synonym for either 696 or 2488 graphs.

GraphClass.name: spider graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is is a 4288 if every vertex vi can be assigned a set Si of points on the circle such that vi and vj are adjacent iff there exist a,b in Si and x,y in Sj such that a<x<b<y or x<a<y<b.

GraphClass.name: $N^*$
GraphClass.note:
Define a preorder <v of the nodes of a graph by: x<vy iff N'(x) \subseteq N[y], where N'(x) is the set of nodes at distance 1 or 2 from x.
A graph is an 4328 if in all induced subgraphs any two vertices are comparable with respect to <v.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: If a (P,N) partition is given, they can be recognized in O(V+E log V) time ref_1280 ref_1199

GraphClass.name: (6,1)-even-chordal
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4368 if every even cycle of length at least 6 has at least 1 chord.
Confusion danger: The class 5648 is sometimes also called 4376.

GraphClass.name: domination perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4392 if for every induced subgraph H a minimum dominating set has the same cardinality as a minimum independent dominating set. Note that a set is independent dominating set iff it is maximal independent.

GraphClass.name: middle
GraphClass.note: The middle graph of G=(V,E) is the intersection graph of V\cup E. A graph is a 4408 graph if it is the middle graph of some graph.

GraphClass.name: indifference
GraphClass.note:
A vertex order is an indifference order iff for every P_3 abc : a<b and b<c or a<b and b<a
A graph is an 4440 graph if it admits an indifference order.
A graph is an 4440 graph if it admits an acyclic orientation in which every P_3 is oriented as o->o->o.

GraphClass.name: chordal-perfect
GraphClass.note:
The P_4-structureref_206 of a graph G is a hypergraph having the the node of G as its vertex set and all 4-element vertex sets inducing a P_4 in G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 4456 iff it has the P_4-structure of a 256 graph.

GraphClass.name: irredundance perfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x is said to be redundant in a vertex set X if N[x] - N[X\x] is empty. A set that contains no redundant vertices is irredundant. The irredundance number ir(G) of G is the minimum cardinality taken over all maximal irredundant vertex sets of G.
The cardinality of a minimum dominating set of G is called the domination number \gamma(G).
A graph is 4480 if for every induced subgraph H: ir(H) = \gamma(H).

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: The number of cliques is polynomially bounded ref_666.

GraphClass.name: weak dominating pair
GraphClass.note:
A pair of vertices in a graph is called a dominating pair if the vertex set of every path between these two vertices is a dominating set.
A graph is a 4544 graph if it has a dominating pair.

GraphClass.name: diametral path
GraphClass.note:
A diametral path of a graph is a shortest path whose length is equal to the diameter of the graph.
A graph is a 4552 if every connected induced subgraph has a dominating diametral path.

GraphClass.name: homogeneously representable
GraphClass.note: An 1872 graph G is 4568 if for every vertex v there is an interval representation of G such that v is represented by an end interval.

GraphClass.name: reflexive
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4648 if for every node v there is an edge (v,v) (a loop).

GraphClass.name: $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A complete graph on k nodes is a 4752.
If G is a 4752 and C is a k-clique of G, then the graph formed by adding a new vertex to G, and making it adjacent to all nodes of C is a 4752.

GraphClass.name: partial $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note: G is a 4760 if it is a spanning subgraph of a 4752

GraphClass.name: interval regular
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is 4800 if for any two vertices u, v the number of neighbours of u on all shortest (u,v)-paths equals d(u,v).

GraphClass.name: interval regular of diameter 2
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is 4808 if every pair of nonadjacent vertices has exactly two paths of length 2 between them, i.e. has exactly two common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: bipartite tolerance
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph is a 4816 graph if there is a tolerance t and a function f from vertices to real numbers such that xy is an edge iff |f(x) - f(y)| <= t.
Since this class is equal to 8104, but not equal to 8072, it would be more appropriate to call it bipartite bounded tolerance graphs.

GraphClass.name: D
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 4832 if each induced subgraph contains a vertex x such that for any edge yz with y,z not neighbours of x, y dominates z or vice versa.

GraphClass.name: domishold
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 4840 if there is a threshold S and every vertex v has a positive real weight w(v) such that U is a dominating set iff the sum of the weights of the vertices in U exceeds S.
A graph is a 4840 if it can be generated from the empty graph by the operation: G' = (G \cup pK_1) \times K_{r,r} \times K_q, with p+q+r > 0.

GraphClass.name: totally unimodular
GraphClass.note:
A matrix is totally unimodular if the determinant of every induced square submatrix is equal to -1,0, or +1
A graph is 4848 if its clique matrix is totally unimodular.

GraphClass.name: split-neighbourhood
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4864 if every induced subgraph has a vertex whose neighbourhood induces a 312 graph.

GraphClass.name: pretty
GraphClass.note: A graph is 4872 if every induced subgraph has a vertex whose neighbourhood is 1368.

GraphClass.name: p-tree
GraphClass.note:
G is a p-cycle if every vertex of G is contained in at least two P_4s and every proper induced subgraph of G has a vertex occuring in at most 1 P_4.
A graph is a 4888 if it is 2784 and contains no p-cycle.
Forbidden subgraphs for 864.
Forbidden subgraphs for 280.

GraphClass.name: nearly bipartite
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 5120 if for every node v, G-N[v] is 552.

The following different classes are sometimes also called 5120:
Graphs that can be made 552 by deleting one vertex.
Graphs that can be made 552 by deleting at most k nodes, for fixed k.

GraphClass.name: concave-round
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5128 if its vertices can be circularly enumerated such that the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is an interval in the enumeration.

GraphClass.name: convex-round
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5136 if its vertices can be circularly enumerated such that the open neighbourhood of every vertex is an interval in the enumeration.

GraphClass.name: circular convex bipartite
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph (X,Y,E) is 5152 if X can be circularly ordered such that for every vertex in Y, its neighbourhood is an interval of the ordering.

GraphClass.name: interval enumerable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5168 if its vertices can be linearly ordered such that for every vertex its lower numbered neighbours form an interval in the ordering.

GraphClass.name: k-leaf power, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a 5192 if there is a tree T whose leaves correspond to the vertices of G in such a way that two vertices are adjacent in G precisely when their distance in T is at most k.

GraphClass.name: 4-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5200 it it results from replacing every vertex of a 6160 by a clique of arbitrary size.

GraphClass.name: 3-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A connected graph is a 5208 iff it results from at tree by replacing every vertex by a clique of arbitrary size.

GraphClass.name: (1,2)-polar
GraphClass.note:
A 5320 graph is a graph G whose vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that the connected components of co-G[A] and G[B] are complete graphs of size at most 1, 2, respectively.
Note that this means that G[A] is a clique.

GraphClass.name: perfect connected-dominant
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5344 if for every induced subgraph H, the size of a minimum dominating set and the size of a connected minimum dominating set are equal.
This class is defined by some forbidden subgraphs for 3776 graphs.

algo.name: Independent set
algo.note: 5400 are precisely the 3776 graphs of 344 graphs.

algo.name: Cutwidth
algo.note: From ref_1648 and ref_1509.

GraphClass.name: charming
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v of a graph G is called charming iff it is not the endpoint of a P_5 in G, not the endpoint of a P_5 in the complement of G and does not lie on a C_5 of G.
A graph is 5408 if every induced subgraph has a charming vertex.
Every graph in this graphclass is either a clique or possesses two non-adjacent charming vertices.

GraphClass.name: slim
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5440 if it can be obtained from a 1552 graph by deleting all edges between an arbitrary set of nodes.
5448 were introduced as 5440 graphs.

GraphClass.name: 1-bounded bipartite
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph (X,Y,E) is 5480 if every vertex in X, resp. Y, has at most 1 non-neighbour in Y, resp. X.

GraphClass.name: 2-bounded bipartite
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph (X,Y,E) is 5496 if every every vertex in X, resp. Y, has at most 2 non-neighbour in Y, resp. X.

GraphClass.name: 1-bounded tripartite
GraphClass.note: A 3624 graph is 5512 if every vertex in partite set Xi has at most 1 non-neighbour in every partite set Xj, i unequal to j.

GraphClass.name: upper irredundance perfect
GraphClass.note:
A vertex x is said to be redundant in a vertex set X if N[x] - N[X\x] is empty. A set that contains no redundant vertices is irredundant. The upper irredundance number IR(G) of G is the maximum cardinality taken over all irredundant vertex sets of G.
The maximum cardinality of a minimum dominating set of G is called the upper domination number \Gamma(G).
A graph is 5520 if for every induced subgraph H: IR(H) = \Gamma(H).

GraphClass.name: upper domination perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5528 if for every induced subgraph the maximum cardinality of a minimal dominating set equals the maximum cardinality of an independent set.

GraphClass.name: strong domination perfect
GraphClass.note:
A set X is called a strong dominating set of G=(V,E), if every every vertex u in V-X is adjacent to a vertex v in X such that d(v)>=d(u), where d(x) is the degree of vertex x.
An independent strong dominating set of G is a strong dominating set that is independent.
A graph is 5552 if for every induced subgraph the size of a minimal strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal dominating set.
For every induced subgraph the size of a minimal independent strong dominating set equals the size of a minimal independent dominating set.

GraphClass.name: clique-perfect
GraphClass.note:
A clique-transversal of a graph G is a set of vertices intersecting all the maximal cliques of G. A clique-independent set of G is a set of pairwise disjoint maximal cliques of G.
A graph is 5592 if for every induced subgraph the size of a minimum clique-transversal equals the size of a maximum clique-independent set.

GraphClass.name: slender
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5616 if it can be obtained from a 1528 graph G by deleting all edges of a matching M in G.

GraphClass.name: skeletal
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5624 if it can be obtained from a 600 graph G by selecting a set of vertices N in G such that the vertices in N have pairwise distance at least 3 and deleting an arbitrary set of edges of G that all have one endpoint in N.

GraphClass.name: quasi-Meyniel
GraphClass.note: A building is a cycle with at least five vertices, with a single chord the forms a triangle with two edges of a cycle (i.e. a single chord that is a short chord). A graph is 5632 if it is 2848 and it has a vertex x that is the endvertex of the chord of every building.
Confusion danger: This class is sometimes called 4376.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of multigraphs without triangles
line graphs of bipartite multigraphs
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5696 iff its 1128 graph is 552.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of Helly hypergraphs of rank 3
GraphClass.note: The rank of a hypergraph is the maximum size of its hyperedges.

GraphClass.name: 3-mino
GraphClass.note: G is a 5720 graph if every vertex of G is contained in at most three maximal cliques of G.

GraphClass.name: line graphs of linear hypergraphs of rank 3
GraphClass.note:
The rank of a hypergraphs is the maximum size of its hyperedges.
A hypergraph is linear if every pair of edges has at most 1 common vertex.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is of 5736 when no vertex has more than 4 neighbours.
A graph is of 5736 if it is XC_{11}-free.
Is every graph of 5736 an 9264?

GraphClass.name: linear domino
GraphClass.note: A 1432 is called linear if every edge belongs to exactly one maximal clique.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 3
GraphClass.note: A graph is of 5760 when no vertex has more than 3 neighbours.
A graph is of 5760 if it is XC_{12}-free.

GraphClass.name: maximal outerplanar
GraphClass.note: An 880 graph is 5784 if it is not possible to add an edge such that the resulting graph is still 880.

GraphClass.name: rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let R be a collection of rectangles in the plane, such that each rectangle has its sides parallel to the axes. Rectangles may share boundary points, but not interior points. We say that two rectangles u, v are visible to each other if there is an axis-parallel rectangle (of non-zero width), called band of visibility, with opposite sides that are subsets of u and v and that intersects no other rectangle of R.
The visibility graph of R is the graph of the visibility relation of the elements of R.
A graph is a 5792 if it is the visibility graph of some collection of rectangles.
5800 are sometimes also called 5792.

GraphClass.name: weak rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5800 graph if it can be drawn in the plane such that vertices are represented by rectangles that are aligned with the axes and edges are horizontal or vertical lines of sight (note that not every line of sight need to be an edge).

GraphClass.name: partial rectangle visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5808 graph if it is a (not necessarily induced) subgraph of a 5792.

GraphClass.name: bar visibility
GraphClass.note:
Let B be a collection of closed horizontal line segments in the plane, pairwise disjoint except for possibly shared endpoints. We say that two segments u, v are visible to each other if there is a vertical rectangle (of non-zero width), called band of visibility, with opposite sides that are subsets of u and v and that intersects no other segment of B.
The visibility graph of B is the graph of the visibility relation of the elements of B.
A graph is a 5816 if it is the visibility graph of some collection of horizontal line segments.

GraphClass.name: thickness \le 2
GraphClass.note:
A graph is of thickness k if it can be decomposed into k 344 graphs, but not into k-1 344 graphs.
A graph is of 5824 if it either is 344 or is the union of 2 344 graphs.

GraphClass.name: biplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph is 5832 if it is the union of 2 344 graphs.
5832 is also used for graphs that have thickness precisely 2, instead of thickness at most 2 (see 5824 for a definition of thickness).

GraphClass.name: weak bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5840 graph if it can be drawn in the plane such that vertices are represented by horizontal line segments and edges are vertical lines of sight of non-zero width (note that not every line of sight need be an edge).

GraphClass.name: partial bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5848 graph if it is a (not necessarily induced) subgraph of a 5816 graph.

GraphClass.name: caterpillar arboricity \le 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has 5856 if it can be decomposed into (is the union of) at most 2 forests whose connected components are 6272.

GraphClass.name: linear arboricity \le 2
GraphClass.note: A graph has 5864 if it can be decomposed into (is the union of) at most 2 forests whose connected components are linear forests (=paths).

GraphClass.name: partial 4--tree
GraphClass.note: See 4760

GraphClass.name: gridline
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5888 graph if it can be drawn in the plane with vertices adjacent whenever they are on a common vertical or horizontal line.
A graph is a 5888 graph if it is 3528 and its 1128 graph is 552.

GraphClass.name: frame hereditary dominating pair
GraphClass.note:
Three vertices of a graph form an asteroidal triple if every two of them are connected by a path avoiding the neighbourhood of the third.
A graph G is 5904 (frame HDP) if it is a 4536 graph with an asteroidal triple T such that all vertices of G are on an induced path between two vertices of T that avoid the neighbourhood of the third vertex of T.

GraphClass.name: grid intersection
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5912 graph iff it is the intersection graph of horizontal and vertical line segments in the plane.

GraphClass.name: string
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 5928 graph if it is the intersection graph of curves in the plane.
A graph is 5976 iff every triangle contains an edge such that any common neighbour of the vertices of the edge is also adjacent to the third vertex of the triangle.

A set S of sets Si has the strong Helly property if the cardinality of the intersection of all Si equals the cardinality of the intersection of Si and Sj, for all i!=j.
A graph is 5976 iff its clique hypergraph has the strong Helly property.
A graph is 5984 iff it does contain XZ_{15} as an induced subgraph.

GraphClass.name: maximal clique irreducible
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 5992 if every maximal clique in G contains an edge that is not contained in any other maximal clique.

GraphClass.name: unit bar visibility
GraphClass.note: A 5816 graph is a 6008 if it has a visibility representation with all bars of unit length.

GraphClass.name: circular perfect
GraphClass.note:
For 1<=d<=k, let Kk/d be the graph with vertices 0,1...k-1 and edges ij iff d<=|i-j|<=k-d. For example, an odd-hole C2n+1 equals K(2n+1)/n and the co-cycle co-Cn equals Kn/2.
A homomorphism from a graph G to a graph H is a mapping f:V(G)->V(H) such that f(x)f(y) \in E(H) whenever xy\in E(G).
The circular chromatic number \chi_c(G) of a graph G is the minimal k/d such that a homomorphism from G to Kk/d exists. In other words, \chi_c(G) is the minimal k/d for which a function f: V(G) -> {0,..,k-1} exist such that for adjacent vertices x,y: d<=|f(x)-f(y)|<=k-d.
The circular clique number \omega_c(G) of a graph G is the maximal k/d such that a homomorphism from Kk/d to G exists.
A graph is 6024 if for every induced subgraph H, \chi_c(H) = \omega_c(H).

GraphClass.name: biclique separable
GraphClass.note: A biclique cutset is a cutset that induces the disjoint union of two cliques (so a biclique cutset induces the complement of a biclique!). A graph is 6032 if it is 3496 and each induced subgraph that is not a clique contains a clique cutset or a biclique cutset.
A graph is 6112 it its vertex set can be partitioned into three, possibly empty, sets C, S, I, such that C is a clique, S, I are independent sets and there is a join between C and S.

GraphClass.name: square of tree
GraphClass.note: Given a graph G=(V,E), Gk=(V,E') has an edge (u,v) iff dG(u,v) <= k.

G is a 6160 iff it is 256, 6168 and its maximal cliques have the following properties:
Every two distinct maximal cliques have at most two vertices in common.
Every 2-cut belongs to exactly two maximal cliques.
Every pair of non-disjoint 2-cuts belongs to the same maximal clique.
All 2-cuts contained in the same maximal clique of G have a common vertex.

GraphClass.name: 2-connected
GraphClass.note: A graph is k-connected if it cannot be disconnected by removing less than k vertices.

GraphClass.name: basic 4-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6200 if it is a 5200 such that to every internal vertex of the corresponding tree only one leaf is attached.
A graph is a 6200 if it is an induced subgraph of a 6160.
A graph is a 6200 if every block is a 6160, and for every non-disjoint pair of block, at least one of them is a clique.

GraphClass.name: cycle-bicolorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6216 if its vertices can be coloured with 2 colours such that the colours alternate on every induced cycle of length at least 4.

GraphClass.name: alternately colourable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6224 if its edges can be coloured with 2 colours such that the colours alternate on every induced cycle of length at least 4.

GraphClass.name: Bouchet
GraphClass.note: Let the local complement G*v result from G by complementing G[N(v)]. Two graphs are said to be locally equivalent if one results from the other by a series of local complements. Note that this is an equivalence relation. A graph G is a 6240 graph iff no induced subgraph of G is locally equivalent to W_5,BW_3 or W_7.

GraphClass.name: quasi-threshold
GraphClass.note:
6248 graphs are defined recursively as follows:
K_1 is a 6248 graph
Adding a new vertex adjacent to all vertices of a 6248 graph results in a 6248 graph
The disjoint union of two 6248 graphs results in a 6248 graph.

GraphClass.name: graceful
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with e edges. A numbering f of the vertices of G with distinct numbers from 0..e is called graceful if, when edges (x,y) are labelled with |f(x)-f(y)|, different edges have different labels.
A graph is 6264 if it has a graceful numbering.
*** 2736s are 6264. (Ringel-Kotzig, see ref_1329).

GraphClass.name: caterpillar
GraphClass.note: A caterpillar is a 2736 that has a dominating path.

GraphClass.name: harmonious
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with e edges. A numbering f of the vertices of G with distinct numbers from 0..e-1 is called harmonious if, when edges (x,y) are labelled with f(x)+f(y) (mod e), different edges have different labels.
A graph is 6280 if it has a harmonious numbering.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
Let G be a 552 graph with vertex partition (U,N), not necessarily a bipartition, where G(N) is an independent set. A U-star is either a star with a vertex of maximum degree in U and pendants in N, or a K_2 with both vertices in U.
A 552 graph G is in 6320 if there exists a vertex partition (U,N) with G(N) independent such that the edges of G can be partitioned into consecutively orderable U-stars.

GraphClass.name: disk-Helly
GraphClass.note: A synonym for 840.
This class is characterised by forbidding subgraphs for 6088

GraphClass.name: subtree filament
GraphClass.note:
A graph is a 6480 graph if it has an intersection model of the following form:
Let T be a tree in a plane P and let t1,...tn be subtree of T.Subtree filaments on the subtree ti are constructed in a surface perpendicular to P whose intersection with P is exactly T. In this surface, in and above T, we construct filaments f1,...,fn where each fi is a curve connecting the leaves of ti such that (i) filaments corresponding to disjoint subtrees do not intersect, and (ii) filaments corresponding to overlapping subtrees intersect. Filaments corresponding to subtrees on of which is contained in the other may or may not intersect.
This is the largest probe class that is a subclass of 112 ref_1354.

GraphClass.name: 5-leaf power
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a 6600 if there is a tree T whose leaves correspond to the vertices of G in such a way that two vertices are adjacent in G precisely when their distance in T is at most 5.
Give a structural characterisation of 6600s ref_1356.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Polynomial if a probe partition is given ref_1359.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Polynomial if a probe partition is given ref_1359.

GraphClass.name: CIS
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6656 if each maximal clique intersects each maximal stable (= independent) set.

GraphClass.name: almost CIS
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6664 if it has a unique disjoint pair (C,S) consisting of a maximal clique C and a maximal independent set S.
A graph is 6664 if it is a 312 graph with a unique split partition.
When a 312 graph does not have a unique split partition, then it is a 6656 (but not vice versa).

GraphClass.name: module-composed
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6672 if its vertices can be ordered v1...vn, such that the neighbourhood of vi is a module of the graph induced by v1...vi-1. The ordering v1...vn is called the module sequence of the graph.

GraphClass.name: independent module-composed
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 6680 if its vertices can be ordered v1...vn, such that the neighbourhood of vi is both an independent set in G and a module of the graph induced by v1...vi-1. The ordering v1...vn is called the independent module sequence of the graph.

An edge ab of G is a symmetric wing if there exist vertices c,d,p,q such that both abcd and bapq are P_4s in G.
A graph is 6760 iff it contains no symmetric wing.

GraphClass.name: binary tree
GraphClass.note: A 2736 is a 6776 if every vertex has degree at most 3. If a root is appointed in the tree, then every vertex has at most 2 children, hence the name binary.

GraphClass.name: 3d grid
GraphClass.note: An $k\times n\times m$ 6792 is the cartesian product of three paths $P_k$, $P_n$ and $P_m$.

GraphClass.name: partial 3d grid
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6800 iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a 6792.

GraphClass.name: semicircular
GraphClass.note: A graph is 6808 if it has an intersection model consisting of open semicircles on a circle. In other words, it is a 1064 graph that has a circular arc model in which every arc is open and spans 180 degrees of the circle.

GraphClass.name: normal circular arc
GraphClass.note: A 1064 graph is a 6888 graph if it admits a circular arc model such that no two arcs cover the circle.
Characterize 6888 graphs and give a recognition algorithm.

GraphClass.name: SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6896 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments in the plane.

GraphClass.name: k-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6904 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most k directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 2-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6912 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 2 directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 1-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6920 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 1 direction in the plane.

GraphClass.name: PURE-k-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6928 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most k directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: PURE-2-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6936 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 2 directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: PURE-3-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6944 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 3 directions in the plane, with the additional condition that any two parallel segments are disjoint.

GraphClass.name: 1-string
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 6960 graph if it is the intersection graph of strings in the plane, such that any two strings intersect at most once.
The neighbourhood of every vertex is 1368.

GraphClass.name: semiperfectly orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex is semisimplicial in G if it is midpoint of no P_4 in G.
A vertex ordering v1...vn is a semiperfect elimination ordering of G if vi is semisimplicial in the graph induced by v1...vi.
A graph is 6976 if it has a semiperfect elimination order.

GraphClass.name: 2-terminal series--parallel
GraphClass.note:
A two-terminal labelled graph (G,s,t) consist of a graph G with a marked source s and sink t.
The series composition of two-terminal labelled graphs (G,s,t) and (H,x,y) with t=x is (G\cup H, s, y).
The parallel composition of (G,s,t) and (H,x,y) with s=x and t=y is (G\cup H, s, t).
A graph is a 7000 if it can be created from single two-terminal labelled edges by series and/or parallel compositions.

GraphClass.name: balanced 2-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7008 grraph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 equal length intervals on a real line.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7016 iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 intervals of length 1 on a real line.

A graph is an (x,x)-interval graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 open intervals of length x with integer endpoints on a real line.
A graph is a 7016 iff it is an (x,x)-interval graphs for some x.

GraphClass.name: (2,2)-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7024 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 open intervals of length 2 with integer endpoints on a real line.
Note that without the condition of integer endpoints this class would simply be equal to 7016.

GraphClass.name: quasi-line
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7032 graph iff the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is the union of two cliques.

GraphClass.name: all-4-simplicial
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 7040 graph iff the closed neighbourhood of every vertex is the union of at most 4 cliques.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Recognition of all-k-simplicial graphs is NP-Complete for all k >= 3 ref_1400.

GraphClass.name: proper interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7056 if it is an 1336 with an intersection model such that no two intervals in the same bipartite set overlap.

GraphClass.name: unit interval bigraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7056 if it is an 1336 with an intersection model such that all intervals have unit length.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $\Delta$ the maximum degree of the graph, assuming the intersection model is given ref_1647

GraphClass.name: proper Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 7112 if it has a circular arc model that is both proper and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a 2376 and a 1640 graph.
A graph is 7112 if it admits a proper circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651.

A graph is 7112 if it admits a proper circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: interval containment bigraph
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is an 7128 if every vertex can be assigned an interval on the real line such that for all $x \in X$ and $y \in Y$: $xy \in E$ iff the interval assigned to $x$ contains the interval assigned to $y$.

GraphClass.name: strongly circular perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 7160 iff both G and its complement are 6024.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: No clique can have more than 4 vertices

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of posets of interval dimension d
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7232 if it is the 576 of a poset of interval dimension d.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: For d >= 3 ref_1093

GraphClass.name: d-trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
Let L1...Ld be d parallel lines in the plane. A d-trapezoid is the polygon obtained by choosing an interval Ii on every line Li and connecting the left, resp. right endpoint of Ii with the left, resp. right endpoint of Ii+1.
A graph is a 7248 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of d-trapezoids between d parallel lines.

algo.name: Treewidth
algo.note: Assuming an intersection model is given ref_1417.

algo.name: Clique cover
algo.note: Assuming an intersection model is given ref_1120.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assume an intersection model is given ref_1120.

GraphClass.name: comparability graphs of dimension d posets
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7256 if it is the 576 of a poset of dimension d. (The dimension of a poset P is the minimal number of linear extensions of P whose intersection is P.)

GraphClass.name: planar of maximum degree 4
GraphClass.note: A graph is 7272 if it is 344 and every vertex has degree at most 4.

GraphClass.name: overlap
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 7304 if its vertices may be put into a one-to-one correspondence with intervals on a line, such that two vertices are adjacent iff there intervals partially overlap, that is, they have non-empty intersection, but neither contains the other.

algo.name: Colourability
algo.note: The chromatic number is at most 5.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: Finite forbidden subgraph characterization.

GraphClass.note: These are precisely the 2968 graphs that are of 5736.

GraphClass.name: locally connected
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 7456 iff for every vertex v, the open neighbourhood N(v) of v induces a connected graph in G.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643.

GraphClass.name: path orderable
GraphClass.note:
A vertex v in a graph G intercepts a path if v is adjacent to at least one vertex of the path and it misses the path otherwise
An ordering v1..vn of the vertices of G such that for each triple v, w, x with v < w < x in the ordering w intercepts each path from v to x, is called a path ordering.
A graph G is 7464 if it admits a path ordering.

GraphClass.name: strong asteroid free
GraphClass.note:
For a graph G and a vertex v of G, let C1...Ck be the connected components of G\N[v]. Let Bi1,...Bil be the connected components of the graph induced by the vertices of Ci in co-G. The Bij are called the blobs of v in G.
An odd strong asteroid of size k in a graph G is a sequence of vertices v0...vk, where k is odd, v1..vk are distinct, v0 = vk and for all i, 0 <= i < k, vi and vi+1 are in the same blob of vi+(k+1)/2 (addition modulo k).
A graph G is 7472 if it does not contain an odd strong asteroid.

GraphClass.name: 3-DIR
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7480 graph if it is the intersection graph of straight line segments lying in at most 3 directions in the plane.

GraphClass.name: 3-DIR contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7488 graph if it is a 7480 graph with the additional condition that no two segments cross (i.e. have no interior point in common).

GraphClass.name: strongly 3-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 7496 if its vertex set can be partitioned into 3 independent sets C1, C2, C3, such that for every vertex v there is an i such v is adjacent to all vertices in Ci.

GraphClass.name: k-starlike
GraphClass.note: Let G be a 256 graph such that its clique tree T is a star. Let X0,...Xn be the maximal cliques of G, with X0 corresponding to the center of T. A graph is 7552 if max |Xi\ X0| = k.
Graphs that have a spanning tree homeomorphic to a star are sometimes also called starlike. Such graphs are incomparable to 7552 graphs.

GraphClass.name: triangulated
GraphClass.note: Synonym for 256.

GraphClass.name: self-clique
GraphClass.note: A graph is 7568 if it is isomorphic to its 1128 graph.
A graph is in 7576 if it is both 7568 and 1640.

Given a graph G and k>=0, the graph Gk has the same vertices as G, two vertices being adjacent in Gk if their distance in G is at most k.
A graph is in 7576 if it is isomorphic to C_nk for some k>=0 such that 3k<n.
A graph is in 7584 if it is both 7568 and 5976.

A vertex-clique duality is a bijection f which maps vertices to cliques and cliques to vertices in such a way that for a vertex v and a clique C, v\in C iff f(C) \in f(v).
A graph is in 7576 if it admits a vertex-clique duality.

Let G be a graph with vertices v1,..,vn and cliques C1,..,Cm. The (0,1) matrix A = (aij) where aij is 1 iff vertex vi belongs to clique Cj is called a clique matrix of G.
A matrix is quasi-symmetric if its families of row and column vectors are identical.
A graph is in 7576 iff it has a quasi-symmetric clique matrix.

GraphClass.name: co--interval mixed
outer-string
GraphClass.note: A graph is an 7608 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of curves lying in a disk, with one endpoint on the boundary of the disk.

GraphClass.name: CONV
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7616 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of convex sets in the plane.

GraphClass.name: disk contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7632 graph if it is a 3312 graph with the additional condition that no two disks have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: coin
GraphClass.note: Alias for 7632

GraphClass.name: triangle contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 7648 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of triangles in a plane such that no two triangles have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: balanced
GraphClass.note:
Let G be a graph with vertices v1,..,vn and cliques C1,..,Cm. The (0,1) matrix A = (aij) where aij is 1 iff vertex vi belongs to clique Cj is called a clique matrix of G.
A (0,1)-matrix is balanced if it does not contain the vertex-edge incidence matrix of an odd-cycle as a submatrix (that is, it contains no square submatrix of odd order with exactly two 1s per row and per column.)
A graph is 7656 if its clique matrix is balanced.
A graph is in 7704 if it is both 7656 and 2856.
A graph G is 7704 if every connected component of G is either 552 or is the join of a complete bipartite graph and a complete graph.
A graph is in 7728 if it is both 7656 and a 1992 graph.

A graph G is 7728 if it is the 1992 graph of a graph R such that:
If U is the set of vertices of R of degree 2 whose two neighbours are adjacent
and E' is het set of edges of R whose both endpoints are the neighbours of one vertex in U,
then R-U is 552 and every edge of R-U that is a member of E' belongs to no cycle of R-U.
A graph is in 7768 if it is both 7656 and 7760.
A graph G is 7768 if the clique matrix (see 7656 of G has no square submatrix of order 3, 5, or 7 with exactly two 1s per row and per column.

GraphClass.name: unit Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 7792 if it has a circular arc model that is both a unit model and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a 2432 and a 1640 graph.
A graph is 7792 if it admits a unit circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651.

A graph is 7792 if it admits a unit circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: 2-thin
GraphClass.note: A graph G=(V,E) is k-thin if there exist an ordering < of the vertices of G and a partition of V into k sets, with the property that, for each triple of vertices r, s, t with r<s<t: if r and s are in the same partitioned set and tr is an edge, then ts is an edge.

The 1872 graphs are precisely the 1-thin graphs.
The thinness of a graph G is the minimum k such that G is k-thin.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming a k-partition is given ref_1463.

GraphClass.name: perfectly colorable
GraphClass.note:
Let \omega(G) be the size of a maximum clique in G.
A perfect coloring of a graph G is a proper coloring of G such that every connected induced subgraph H of G uses exactly \omega(H) many colors.
A graph is 7832 if it admits a perfect coloring.

GraphClass.name: Apollonian network
GraphClass.note:
7840s are defined recursively as follows:
The triangle is an 7840.
If G is an 7840, then the graph obtained by embedding G in the plane, selecting a triangular face F of the embedding, adding a new vertex v inside the face and connecting v to each vertex of F, is again an 7840.
Note that the definition given here differs slightly from that in ref_1469 where all faces are subdivided equally often.

GraphClass.name: maximal planar
GraphClass.note: A 344 graph is 7848 if it is not possible to add an edge such that the graph is still 344.

GraphClass.name: polyhedral
GraphClass.note: A graph is 7888 if it is the graph formed by the vertices and edges of convex polyhedron.

A graph is k-vertex-connected if you need to delete at least k vertices before the resulting graph is disconnected.
A graph is 7888 if it is 3-vertex-connected and 344 (a.k.a. Steinitz' Theorem).

GraphClass.name: $\beta$-perfect
GraphClass.note: A graph is 7896 if for all induced subgraphs H: \chi(H) = \beta(H), where \chi(H) is the chromatic number of H and \beta(H) is the maximum of the minimum degree of the induced subgraphs of H, plus 1.

GraphClass.name: even-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is 7936 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle on at least four vertices even.

GraphClass.name: odd-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is 7944 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle on at least four vertices odd.

GraphClass.name: strongly even-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is 7952 if it can be signed such that every triangle is odd and every induced cycle with at most 1 chord on at least four vertices even.

GraphClass.name: strongly odd-signable
GraphClass.note:
A signing of a graph G assigns every edge of G a label from {0,1}.
Let G be a signed graph. A set of edges is called even if the sum of its labels is even and odd if the sum of its edges is odd.
G is 7960 if it can be signed such that every diamond is even and every induced cycle odd.

GraphClass.name: b-perfect
GraphClass.note:
A b-colouring of a graph G is a colouring of the vertices of G such that each colour class contains a vertex that has a neighbour in every other colour class.
The b-chromatic number of a graph G is the largest integer k such that G admits a b-colouring with k colours.
A graph G is 8024 if for every induced subgraph of G, the b-choromatic number is equal to the chromatic number.

GraphClass.name: homothetic triangle contact
GraphClass.note:
Two triangles are homothetic if they only differ in geometric contraction or expansion.
A graph is a 8040 graph if it has an intersection model consisting of homothetic triangles in a plane such that no two triangles have more than one point in common.

GraphClass.name: max-tolerance
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8056 graph if every vertex v can be assigned a closed interval Iv on the real line and a tolerance tv such that x and y are adjacent iff |Ix \cap Iy| >= max{tx, ty}.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: There are O(V3) maximal cliques in a max-tolerance graph.

GraphClass.name: semi-square intersection
GraphClass.note:
A semi-square is an axis-parallel isosceles triangle (i.e. the lower half of a diagonally cut axis-parallel square).
A graph is a 8064 graph if every vertex can be assigned a semi-square such that two vertices are adjacent iff their semi-squares intersect.

A collection of sets U is consecutively orderable if the sets can be indexed U1,..,Un, such that for all i <= j <= k, whenever x is in Ui and in Uk, then x is in Uj.
A 552 graph G=(V,E) is in 8072 if there exist a consecutively orderable partition of E into stars.

GraphClass.name: biclique--Helly
GraphClass.note:
The biclique hypergraph of G has V(G) as its vertices and the induced maximal complete bipartite subgraphs (bicliques) of G as its hyperedges.
A graph is 8120 iff its biclique hypergraph has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: Helly circle
GraphClass.note: A 1056 graph is a 8136 graph iff it has an intersection model that has the Helly property.

GraphClass.name: unit Helly circle
GraphClass.note: A 1056 graph is a 8152 graph iff it has an intersection model such that all chords in the model are the same size and the model has the Helly property.
A graph is a 8152 graph iff it is a chordless cycle, a complete graph or a disjoint union of chordless paths.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: where $a$ is the arboricity of the graph ref_1645.

GraphClass.name: SC $k$-tree, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A complete graph on k nodes is a 8216 (short for simple-clique k-tree).
If G is a 8216 and C is a k-clique of G not previously chosen in the construction of G, then the graph formed by adding a new vertex to G, and making it adjacent to all nodes of C is a 8216.

GraphClass.name: $k$-path graph, fixed $k$
GraphClass.note:
A k-path of G is an alternating sequence of distinct k- and k+1-cliques of G, [e0, t1, e1,..., tp, ep], starting and ending with a k-clique and such that ti contains exactly two k-cliques, ei-1 and ei.
Let G be a 4752 with more than k vertices. If there is a k-path P in G, such that G and the graph induced by the vertices of the k+1-cliques ti of P are isomorphic, then G is a 8240.
Let G be a 4752 with more than k vertices. G is a 8240 iff G has exactly two simplicial vertices.
A particular type of intersection graph of paths of length k in a graph are sometimes also called k-path graphs, see ref_1492.

GraphClass.name: double-split
GraphClass.note:
A graph G=(V,E) is 8264 if its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets A and B, such that the followings hold:
G[A] is a disjoint union of edges
G[B] is the complement of a disjoint union of edges
for all adjacent u, v in A and all x in B, x is adjacent to exactly one of u and v
for all u in A and all non-adjacent x, y in B, u is adjacent to exactly one of x and y

The proof of the strong perfect graph theorem in ref_1128 uses a decomposition theorem, stating that all 448 graphs either belong to the 552, 3888, 2008, 5952 or the 8264 graph or admit one of several decompositions.

GraphClass.name: doubled
GraphClass.note: A graph G is a 8272 graph if there is a 8264 graph H that contains G as an induced subgraph.

GraphClass.name: almost-split
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8288 if G is 8272 and it contains a vertex v such that G-v is 312.

GraphClass.name: bitolerance
GraphClass.note: Another name for 2176 graphs.

GraphClass.name: normal Helly circular arc
GraphClass.note:
A graph is 8320 if it has a circular arc model that is both normal and Helly.
Note that is stronger than requiring that the graph is both a 6888 and a 1640 graph.

A dismantling of a graph G is the subgraph of G obtained by iteratively removing a vertex which is dominated by some other vertex in the subgraph obtained so far (see also 392). A graph is 8320 iff it is either 1872 or its dismantling is 7576.
A graph is 8320 if it admits a circular arc model in which no two nor three arcs cover the circle. ref_1651

A graph is 8320 if it admits a circular arc model in which no three arcs cover the circle. ref_1659. Note that in any model on at least 3 arcs in which two arcs cover the circle, there are also three arcs that together cover the circle.

GraphClass.name: parallelepiped
GraphClass.note:
Let L and M be two parallel lines in 3-dimensional Euclidean space. Without loss of generality assume L={(.,0,0)} and M={(.,1,0)}.
A special parallelepiped on L and M is either
the convex hull of eight points
A = (a,1,0)A' = (a,1,z)
B = (b,0,0)B' = (b,0,z)
C = (c,0,0)C' = (c,0,z)
D = (d,1,0)D' = (d,1,z)
for some a,b,c,d,z >= 0 with ADBC a parallelogram between L and M; or
the line segment between (a,1,z) and (b,0,z) for some a,b,z >= 0.
A graph is a 8328 graph if it is the intersection graph of special parallelepipeds on two parallel lines.

GraphClass.name: strictly clique irreducible
GraphClass.note: A graph is 8360 if every edge in the graph lies in a unique clique.

Let G be a graph and U be the set of universal vertices of G. G is 8376 iff
G is 7112 or
G\U is both 3888 and 7112, and |U|>= 2.

GraphClass.name: trapezoepiped
GraphClass.note:
Let L and M be two parallel lines in 3-dimensional Euclidean space. Without loss of generality assume L={(.,0,0)} and M={(.,1,0)}.
A special trapezeopiped on L and M is either
the convex hull of eight points
A = (a,1,0)A' = (a,1,a')
B = (b,0,0)B' = (b,0,b')
C = (c,0,0)C' = (c,0,a')
D = (d,1,0)D' = (d,1,b')
for some a,b,c,d,a',b' >= 0 with ADBC a trapezoid between L and M; or
the line segment between (a,1,z) and (b,0,z) for some a,b,z >= 0.
A graph is a 8384 graph if it is the intersection graph of special trapezoepipeds on two parallel lines.

GraphClass.name: bounded bitolerance
GraphClass.note: Another name for 2728 graphs.

GraphClass.name: grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8456 iff it is an induced subgraph of a 3712.

GraphClass.name: solid grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8464 iff it is a 8456 that can be embedded in the plane such that the vertices lie on integer coordinates, the edges have unit length and all interior faces have unit area. (The first two conditions hold for every 8456, the third says that the embedding contains no `holes'.)

GraphClass.name: self-complementary
GraphClass.note: A graph is 8472 if it is isomorphic to its complement.

GraphClass.name: VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8480 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths in a 3712.

GraphClass.name: B_k-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8488 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most k bends in a 3712.

GraphClass.name: B_3-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8496 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 3 bends in a 3712.

GraphClass.name: B_2-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8504 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 2 bends in a 3712.

GraphClass.name: B_1-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8512 graph if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 1 bends in a 3712.

GraphClass.name: B_0-VPG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8520 if it is the vertex intersection graph of paths with at most 0 bends in a 3712.

algo.name: Clique
algo.note: Given that path presentation ref_1545.

GraphClass.name: 4-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 8568 iff it can be partitioned in 4 independent sets.

GraphClass.name: NLCT-width 1
GraphClass.note:
The NLCT-width of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
renaming labels according to a function over the labels (so multiple labels can be renamed by a single operation),
uniting two labeled graphs G and J according to a relation S over the labels: The disjoint union of G and J is created and edges between v in G and w in J are added precisely when the pair (label(v), label(w)) is in S. Furthermore, if S is non-empty, then J must consist of a single vertex.
A graph is in 8576 iff its NLCT-width is at most 1.

GraphClass.name: linear NLC-width 1
GraphClass.note:
The linear NLC-width of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
renaming labels according to a function over the labels (so multiple labels can be renamed by a single operation),
uniting two labeled graphs G and J according to a relation S over the labels: The disjoint union of G and J is created and edges between v in G and w in J are added precisely when the pair (label(v), label(w)) is in S. Furthermore, either G or J must consist of a single vertex.
A graph is in 8584 iff its linear NLC-width is at most 1.
A graph is 8600 iff it can be created from a 2624 graph G, by replacing every vertex in the independent set of the 312 partition of G by a clique.

GraphClass.name: linear cliquewidth 2
GraphClass.note:
The linear cliquewidth of a graph is the number of different labels that is needed to construct the graph using the following operations:
creation of a vertex with label i,
disjoint union of a graph and a single labeled vertex,
renaming labels i to label j,
connecting all vertices with label i to all vertices with label j.
A graph is in 8616 iff its linear cliquewidth is at most 2.

GraphClass.name: 2-track
GraphClass.note: Given 2 parallel lines, a graph is a 8632 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 2 intervals, one on each line.

GraphClass.name: 3-track
GraphClass.note: Given 3 parallel lines, a graph is a 8632 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 3 intervals, one on each line.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8648 iff it is a 8640 graph with an intersection model consisting of unit length intervals.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8656 iff it is a 8632 graph with an intersection model consisting of unit length intervals.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-interval
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8664 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 3 intervals of length 1 on a real line.

GraphClass.name: 2-circular arc
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8672 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 arcs of a circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-circular arc
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8680 graph iff it is a 8672 graph with an intersection model whose objects consist of 2 unit length arcs of a circle.

GraphClass.name: 2-circular track
GraphClass.note: Given 2 disjoint circles, a graph is a 8688 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 2 arcs, one on each circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 2-circular track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8696 graph iff it is a 8688 graph with an intersection model whose objects are 2 unit length arcs.

GraphClass.name: 3-circular track
GraphClass.note: Given 3 disjoint circles, a graph is a 8688 graph iff it has an intersection model whose objects consists of 3 arcs, one on each circle.

GraphClass.name: unit 3-circular track
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8712 graph iff it is a 8704 graph with an intersection model whose objects are 3 unit length arcs.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 7
GraphClass.note: A graph is of 8720 when no vertex has more than 7 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: hamiltonian
GraphClass.note: A graph is 8736 if it has a simple cycle that goes through all vertices of the graph.

GraphClass.name: fully cycle extendable
GraphClass.note:
A cycle in a graph G is extendable if there exists a cycle C' in G that consists of the vertices in C plus a single new vertex.
If every non-hamiltonian cycle in G is extendable, then G is cycle extendable.
If G is cycle extendable and every vertex of G belongs to a triangle of G, then G is 8744.
Every 8784 graph is 8744 ref_1559.

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k\ge 3
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8792 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: cubic
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8800 if every vertex in G has degree 3.
This class is not to be confused with 9416 graphs.

GraphClass.name: 4-regular
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8808 if every vertex in G has degree 4.

GraphClass.name: 5-regular
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8832 if every vertex in G has degree 5.

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k\ge 6
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 8840 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: equimatchable
GraphClass.note:
A set M of edges of a graph is a matching if each vertex in G belongs to at most one edge in M. A matching M is maximal if no other matching strictly contains M.
A graph G is 8896 if all maximal matchings in G have the same cardinality.
A graph G is 8896 if every maximal matching is a maximum matching.
A graph G is 8896 if its 1992 graph is 3320.

GraphClass.name: well-dominated
GraphClass.note: A graph G is well-dominated if every minimal dominating set is a minimum dominating set.

GraphClass.name: triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 8944 iff it is an induced subgraph of a tiling of the plane with equilateral triangles.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 6
GraphClass.note: A graph is of 8952 when no vertex has more than 6 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: solid triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note:
Let G be 8944 and let T be a planar tiling with triangles that contains G.
A hole of G is an interior face of G that contains a vertex in V(T)\V(G).
A graph is a 8992 iff it is a 8944 that has no holes.

GraphClass.name: maximum degree 5
GraphClass.note: A graph is of 9112 when no vertex has more than 5 neighbours.

GraphClass.name: linearly convex triangular grid graph
GraphClass.note: A 8944 G is a 9128 iff every line which contains an edge of the underling triangular tiling is either a line segment (a path in G), or a point (a vertex in G) or empty.

GraphClass.name: almost claw-free
GraphClass.note: Let A be the set of vertices in a graph G that are the centers of an induced claw. A graph G is 9160 if A is independent and for every x in A: the subgraph induced by N(x) has a dominating set of size at most 2.

GraphClass.name: Delaunay
GraphClass.note:
Let P be a set of points in the plane. A triangulation of P is a subdivsion of the plane by edges between vertices in P, such that no edge connecting two vertices in P can be added without destroying planarity.
A Delaunay triangulation is a triangulation D(P) such that no point in P is inside the circumference of any triangle in D(P).
A graph is a 9176 graph if it is the Delaunay triangulation of some set of points in the plane.
For a fixed set of points we have the following relations between edges: 9792 $\subseteq$ 9784 $\subseteq$ 9776 $\subseteq$ 9176

GraphClass.name: distance regular
GraphClass.note:
Let $N^k(v)$ be the set of vertices $x$ in $G$ with $d(v,x) = k$.
A graph $G$ is 9184 if there are numbers $a_i, b_i, c_i$ for $0\le i\le d(G)$ such that if $d(x,y) = j$ then \[\begin{array}{ll} |N(y) \cap N_{j-1}(x)| &= c_j\\ |N(y) \cap N_{j}(x)| &= a_j\\ |N(y) \cap N_{j+1}(x)| &= b_j \end{array}\]

GraphClass.name: k-regular, fixed k
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 9192 if every vertex in G has degree k.

GraphClass.name: tree convex
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is 9200 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: star convex
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is 9208 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that $T$ is a star and for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: triad convex
GraphClass.note: A 552 graph $B=(X,Y,E)$ is 9216 if a tree $T=(X,F)$ can be defined, such that $T$ is a triad and for every vertex $y\in Y$, the neighbourhood of $y$ induces a subtree in $T$.

GraphClass.name: circle-trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
A circle trapezoid is the region that lies between two non-crossing chords of a circle. So if $ab$ and $cd$ are non-crossing chords, with their endpoints in the order $abcd$ on the circle, the boundary of the circle trapezoid $abcd$ consists of the chord $ab$, the arc $bc$, the chord $cd$ and the arc $da$. Alternatively, a circle trapezoid is the convex hull of two disjoint arcs on the circle.
A graph is a 9232 graph if it is the intersection graph of circle trapezoids on a common circle.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1120.

algo.name: Weighted clique
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1120.

GraphClass.name: circular trapezoid
GraphClass.note:
Given two concentric circle $C$ and $D$, a circular trapezoid is the region that lies between two non-crossing line segments that connect points on $C$ with points on $D$. So if $ab$ and $cd$ are non-crossing chords, with $a,c$ on $C$ and $b,d$ on $D$, the boundary of the circular trapezoid $abcd$ consists of the line segment $ab$, the arc $bd$, the segment $dc$ and the arc $ca$.
A graph is a 9240 graph if it is the intersection graph of circular trapezoids.

algo.name: Weighted independent set
algo.note: Assuming the intersection model is given ref_1196.

GraphClass.name: circular strip
GraphClass.note: Another name for 9232 graphs.

GraphClass.name: circle-$n$-gon, fixed $n$
GraphClass.note:
A circle $n$-gon is the region that lies between two $n$ or fewer non-crossing chords of a circle, no chord connecting the arcs between two other chords; the side of a circle $n$-gon are either chords or arcs of the circle.
A graph is a 9256 graph if it is the intersection graph of circle $n$-gons in a common circle.

algo.name: Weighted feedback vertex set
algo.note: Assuming the model is given ref_1595.

GraphClass.name: alternation
GraphClass.note:
Given a word $W$ over the alphabet $V$, we say that the letters $x,y\in V$ alternate in $W$ if between every two occurrences of $x$ there is a $y$ ($x,y,x$ need not be consecutive) and between every two occurrences of $y$ there is an $x$.
A graph $G=(V,E)$ is an 9264 graph if there exists a word $W$ over the alphabet $V$ such that $x, y$ ($x\not= y$) alternate in $W$ iff $xy$ is an edge.

An orientation of a graph $G=(V,E)$ is semi-transitive if it is acyclic and for any directed path $v_1,..,v_k$ either $v_1v_k\not\in E$ or $v_iv_j\in E$ for all $1\le i\lt j\lt k$.
A graph is an 9264 graph iff it is semi-transitively orientable.
Is every graph of 5736 an 9264 graph? ref_1598
What is the maximum alternation number of a graph? ref_1598

GraphClass.name: binary Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
A graph is an 9272 graph if its vertices can be labelled by fixed length bitvectors such that the distance between any two vertices equals the Hamming distance between the corresponding labels.

Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
A graph G is a 9272 graph if G is 552 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$.

GraphClass.name: partial cube
GraphClass.note: Alias for 9288

GraphClass.name: isometric subgraph of a hypercube
GraphClass.note: A subgraph G of H is an isometric subgraph if for every two vertices, the distance between them in G equals the distance in H.

GraphClass.name: Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
A graph is a 9296 graph if its vertices can be labelled by fixed length vectors over a finite alphabet such that the distance between any two vertices equals the Hamming distance between the corresponding labels.
A graph is a 9296 graph if it is an isometric subgraph of a 9304 graph.

GraphClass.name: complete Hamming
GraphClass.note:
The Hamming distance between two vectors is the number of positions in which the two vectors differ.
Let $r_1,..r_d$ be given integers and let $V$ be the set of vectors $a_1,..,a_d$ with $0\le a_i\lt r_i$. Let $E$ be the set of pairs of tuples that have Hamming distance 1. Then $G=(V,E)$ is a 9304 graph.
A graph is a 9296 graph if it is the Cartesian product of $d$ (not necessarily isomorphic) complete graphs.

GraphClass.name: hypercube
GraphClass.note: A 9312 is the 9304 graph for the alphabet $\{0,1\}$.
A 9312 is the Cartesian product of $d$ K_2s.

algo.name: Hamiltonian cycle
algo.note: Every 9312 with more than 2 vertices is 8736 ref_1613.

algo.name: Hamiltonian path
algo.note: Every 9312 with more than 2 vertices is 8736 ref_1613.

GraphClass.name: weakly median
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9336 if it is 1776 and does not contain two vertices with an unconnected triple of common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: almost median
GraphClass.note:
Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
For an edge $pq$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ let $W_{pq}=\{w \mid w\in V \text{ and } d(w,p) \lt d(w,q)\}$ and let $U_{pq} = \{u\in W_{pq} \mid u \text{ is adjacent to a vertex in } W_{qp}\}$.
A graph $G$ is 9360 if it is 552 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$ and for any edge $pq$ of $G$, the subgraph induced by $U_{pq}$ is isometric.

GraphClass.name: semi-median
GraphClass.note:
Define the relation $\Theta$ on the edges of an undirected graph as $pq \Theta rs$ iff $d(p,r) + d(q,s) \not= d(p,s) + d(q,r)$.
For an edge $pq$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ let $W_{pq}=\{w \mid w\in V \text{ and } d(w,p) \lt d(w,q)\}$ and let $U_{pq} = \{u\in W_{pq} \mid u \text{ is adjacent to a vertex in } W_{qp}\}$.
A graph $G$ is 9368 if it is 552 and $\Theta$ is an equivalence relation on the edges of $G$ and for any edge $pq$ of $G$, the subgraph induced by $U_{pq}$ is connected.

GraphClass.name: premedian
GraphClass.note: Alias for 9368

GraphClass.name: unit grid intersection
GraphClass.note: A 5912 graph is a 9384 graph if it has an intersection model in which all line segments have unit length.

GraphClass.name: cubical
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9416 iff it is an induced subgraph of a 9312.
This class is not to be confused with 8800 graphs.

GraphClass.name: rigid circuit
GraphClass.note: Synonym for 256.

GraphClass.name: rectangle intersection
GraphClass.note: 9432 graphs or plain rectangle graphs are synonyms for 1912.

GraphClass.name: apex
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is an 9448 graph, if it contains a vertex $v$ such that $G-v$ is 344.

GraphClass.name: 5-colorable
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9456 iff it can be partitioned in 5 independent sets.

GraphClass.name: k--outerplanar
GraphClass.note: A graph G is 9472 if for k=1, G is 880 and for k>1, G has a planar embedding such that if all vertices on the exterior face are deleted, the connected components of the remaining graph are all (k-1) outerplanar.

GraphClass.name: strongly regular
GraphClass.note: A 9480 graph with parameters $(n,k,\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices which is regular of degree $k$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
The parameters $(n,k,\lambda,\mu)$ satisfy the equation \[ k(k-\lambda-1) = (n-k-1)\mu \]

GraphClass.name: distance regular of diameter 2
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9488 iff it is 9184 and its diameter is 2.
A graph is 9488 iff it is connected and 9480.

GraphClass.name: walk regular
GraphClass.note:
A walk is an alternating sequence of vertices and edges, beginning and ending with a vertex, where each vertex is incident to both the edge that precedes it and the edge that follows it in the sequence, and where the vertices that precede and follow an edge are the end vertices of that edge. A walk is closed if its first and last vertices are the same.
A graph is 9496 if, for every non-negative integer $i$ and vertex $v$ the number of closed walks of length $i$ starting at $v$ depends only on $i$, not on $v$.
A graph is 9496 if the characteristic polynomials of all its vertex-deleted subgraphs are the same.

GraphClass.name: edge regular
GraphClass.note: A 9504 graph with parameters $(n,k,\lambda)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices which is regular of degree $k$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: Deza
GraphClass.note: A 9512 graph with parameters $(\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph such that any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
A graph is 9520 iff any two vertices have at most two common neighbours.

GraphClass.name: (0,2)-graph
GraphClass.note: A 9528 is a connected graph such that any two vertices have either 0 or 2 common neighbours.
The 3904 graphs are different, but have a similar naming scheme.

GraphClass.name: rectagraph
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 9536 iff it is 2968 and a 9528.

A semibiplane is a connected point-block incidence structure such that any two points are in either 0 or 2 common blocks and any two blocks have either 0 or 2 common points.
A graph is in 9544 iff it is the incidence graph of a semibiplane.
A connected graph is in 9552 iff it is one of K_1, K_2, K_3, K_4, C_4, C_5, \co{3K_2}.

GraphClass.name: 2-strongly regular
GraphClass.note: A 9560 graph with parameters $(n,k_1\lt k_2,\lambda,\mu)$ is a graph on $n$ vertices in which every vertex is of degree $k_1$ or $k_2$, any two adjacent vertices have exactly $\lambda$ common neighbours and any two nonadjacent vertices have exactly $\mu$ common neighbours.
9560 graphs have diameter at most 2.

GraphClass.name: adjoint
GraphClass.note:
Let $H=(X,V)$ be a directed graph, possibly with multi-edges. The adjoint $G=(V,U)$ of $H$ has vertex set $V$ and $x\rightarrow y$ is an arc in $G$ iff the terminal endpoint of $x$ in $H$ is the initial endpoint of $y$ in $H$.
A directed graph $G$ is an 9576 if there is some directed graph $H$ such that $G$ is the adjoint of $H$.

Let $N^+(x)$ be the out-neighbourhood of $x$.
A directed graph $G$ is an 9576 iff for any two vertices $x,y$ of $G$: If $N^+(x) \cap N^+(y) \neq\emptyset$ then $N^+(x) = N^+(y)$.

GraphClass.name: quasi-adjoint
GraphClass.note:
Let $N^+(x)$ be the out-neighbourhood of $x$.
A directed graph $G$ is a 9584 iff for any two vertices $x,y$ of $G$: If $N^+(x) \cap N^+(y) \neq\emptyset$ then $N^+(x) \subseteq N^+(y)$ or $N^+(y) \subseteq N^+(x)$, that is, the out-neighborhoods are nested.

GraphClass.name: directed line
GraphClass.note: A directed graph $G$ is a 9592 graph if it is the 9576 of a directed graph without multi-edges.

GraphClass.name: partial directed line
GraphClass.note: A directed graph is a 9600 graph iff it is an arbitrary subgraph (not necessarily induced) of a 9592.

GraphClass.name: unicyclic
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9616 if it is connected and contains precisely one cycle.

GraphClass.name: k-SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 9624 graph if it is the intersection graph of piecewise linear curves in the plane, such that each curve consists of at most k line segments.

GraphClass.name: 2-SEG
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 9632 graph if it is the intersection graph of piecewise linear curves in the plane, such that each curve consists of at most 2 line segments.

GraphClass.name: B_1-VPG contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 9640 graph if it is 8512 with the additional condition that no two paths in the model have an interior point in common.

GraphClass.name: Laman
GraphClass.note: A graph with $n$ vertices is a 9648 graph iff, for all $k$, every $k$-vertex induced subgraph has at most $2k-3$ edges and the graph itself has exactly $2n-3$ edges.

A graph is a 9648 graph iff it can be constructed from an edge by a sequence of the following two (so called Henneberg) operations:
Add a new vertex and connect it with two new edges to two existing vertices.
Choose an existing edge $(v,w)$ and a third vertex $x$. Remove the edge $(v,w)$. Add a new vertex $u$ and edges $(u,v), (u,w), (u,x)$
Laman graphs derive their name from Gerard Laman and are of importance in rigidity theory, where they characterize minimally rigid planar bar-and-joint systems.

GraphClass.name: strict B_1-VPG contact
GraphClass.note: A graph is a 9664 graph (called L-contact graph in ref_1638) if it is a 9640 graph with the additional condition that every path in the model has 1 bend.
There are 9664 graphs that are not 9648 graphs (e.g. K_4). All 9664 graphs are 344 and satisfy $|E(W)| \le 2|W|-2$ for all $W \subseteq V$. Are these conditions sufficient? ref_1638.

GraphClass.name: generically minimally rigid
GraphClass.note: 9672 is another name for 9648 graphs.

GraphClass.name: Mycielski
GraphClass.note:
Given a graph $G$, $M(G)$ is constructed as follows: Start with $G$ and for every vertex $v_i$ in $G$ add a vertex $u_i$. Make $u_i$ adjacent to all vertices in $N_G(v_i)$. Finally add a vertex $w$ which is adjacent to all $u_i$.
The 9720 graphs are defined as follows:
K_2 is a 9720 graph.
If $G$ is a 9720 graph, then $M(G)$ is a 9720 graph.

GraphClass.name: hereditary sat
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is a 9744 if its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A$ and $B$ (both possibly empty), such that $G[A]$ is a clique, every vertex in $G[B]$ has degree at most 1 and in $G$ there is no triangle with one vertex in $A$ and two in $B$.

GraphClass.name: locally split
GraphClass.note: A graph is 9752 if the open neighbourhood of each vertex induces a 312 graph.

algo.name: Recognition
algo.note: with $a$ the arboricity of the graph ref_1643.

GraphClass.name: (1,2)-split
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is 9760 iff its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A, B$, such that $G[A]$ is a clique and $G[B]$ is 2968.
Give a forbidden subgraph characterisation of 9760 graphs. ref_1670

GraphClass.name: (p,q)-split
GraphClass.note: A graph $G$ is ($p$,$q$)-split iff its vertex set can be partitioned into two sets $A, B$, such that the largest independent set in $A$ has at most $p$ vertices and the largest clique in $B$ has at most $q$ vertices.

GraphClass.name: Gabriel
GraphClass.note:
Let $P$ be a set of points in the plane. In the Gabriel graph of $P$ there is an edge between $p$ and $q$ iff the circle having $pq$ as a diameter contains no other point of $P$.
A graph is a 9776 graph if it is the Gabriel graph of some set of points in the plane.
For a fixed set of points we have the following relations between edges: 9792 $\subseteq$ 9784 $\subseteq$ 9776 $\subseteq$ 9176

GraphClass.name: Urquhart
GraphClass.note: Let $P$ be a set of points in the plane and let $T$ be a 9176 triangulation of $P$. The Urquhart graph of $P$ is obtained by removing the longest edge of every triangle in $T$. A graph is a 9784 graph if it is the Urquhart graphs of some set of points in the plane.
For a fixed set of points we have the following relations between edges: 9792 $\subseteq$ 9784 $\subseteq$ 9776 $\subseteq$ 9176

GraphClass.name: relative neighbourhood graph
GraphClass.note: Let $P$ be a set of points in the plane. In the 9792 of $P$ there is an edge between $p$ and $q$ iff there is no point $r\in P$ such that $r$ is closer to both $p$ and $q$ than they are to each other: $d(p,q) \le \max\{d(p,r), d(q,r)\}$. A graph is a 9792 if it is the 9792 of some set of points in the plane.
For a fixed set of points we have the following relations between edges: 9792 $\subseteq$ 9784 $\subseteq$ 9776 $\subseteq$ 9176

GraphClass.name: girth >=9
GraphClass.note: A graph has 9800 if it has no cycles with less than 9 vertices.
A graph is 9816 iff it is a complete graph.
